questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of fever, chills, night sweats, and progressive shortness of breath for 1 week. She also reports generalized fatigue and nausea. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypothyroidism. Current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, and levothyroxine. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 104/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Examination shows pale conjunctivae and small nontender hemorrhagic macules over her palms and soles. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. A grade 2/6 mid-diastolic murmur is heard best at the third left intercostal space and is accentuated by leaning forward. The spleen is palpated 1–2 cm below the left costal margin. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.6 g/dL


Leukocyte count
18,300/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
48 mm/h


Urine



Protein
1+


Blood
2+


RBCs
20-30/hpf


WBCs
0-2/hpf


An echocardiography shows multiple vegetations on the aortic valve. Blood cultures grow S. gallolyticus. She is treated with ampicillin and gentamicin for  2 weeks and her symptoms resolve. A repeat echocardiography at 3 weeks shows mild aortic regurgitation with no vegetations. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Indications for aortic valve replacement in IE include severe destruction of the valve, leading to aortic regurgitation and heart failure, persistent infection despite appropriate antibiotic treatment, and infections with difficult-to-treat pathogens (e.g., fungi, resistant organisms), among others. Since this patient has made a full recovery and the repeat echocardiography shows only mild aortic regurgitation, surgery is not indicated at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Warfarin is used for antithrombotic therapy but it is not required to treat IE. Although indications for anticoagulants (e.g., prosthetic heart valves, atrial fibrillation, venous thromboembolism) are frequently present in patients with IE, none are seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with a history of endocarditis should receive antibiotic prophylaxis when undergoing procedures with an increased risk of bacteremia, particularly dental procedures. Antibiotics recommended for prophylaxis include amoxicillin, ampicillin, clarithromycin, and azithromycin. Ciprofloxacin is more commonly used to treat bacterial gastroenteritis and urinary tract infections; it is, therefore, not indicated in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Implantable defibrillators are used to prevent possible sudden cardiac death in patients with an increased risk of ventricular fibrillation (VF) and/or ventricular tachycardia (VT). The most common indications include a history of VF/VT, severe congestive heart failure (CHF), and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. While CHF can occur as a possible complication of IE, this patient shows no clinical signs of heart failure.

E) CORRECT:

Streptococcus gallolyticus can be found in the normal bowel flora of healthy humans. A link between S. gallolyticus bacteremia, particularly in endocarditis, and colorectal cancer has been well established. However, it remains unclear whether this pathogen is part of the etiology of colorectal malignancies or a consequence of the disease. A colonoscopy is indicated in all patients with S. gallolyticus on blood culture.

F) INCORRECT:

The finding of Streptococcus gallolyticus bacteremia is associated with colonic malignancies. Although a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis can be helpful in the detection and staging of colon cancer, it is not the initial test of choice.

G) INCORRECT:

An esophagogastroduodenoscopy can be used to detect malignancies and other diseases in the upper gastrointestinal tract. The finding of S. gallolyticus bacteremia, however, is associated with malignancies in the lower intestines.
questions.hint: This patient has definite infective endocarditis (IE) according to the Duke criteria, with 2 major criteria (typical organism cultured in blood cultures, valvular vegetations) and 3 minor criteria (fever, Janeway lesions, signs of glomerulonephritis on urinalysis) being fulfilled. The cultured pathogen is associated with another life-threatening disease.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for medical clearance for a molar extraction. He feels well. He reports he is able to climb 3 flights of stairs without experiencing any shortness of breath. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and ischemic heart disease. He underwent an aortic valve replacement for severe aortic stenosis last year. Twelve years ago, he underwent a cardiac angioplasty and had 2 stents placed. Current medications include aspirin, warfarin, lisinopril, metformin, sitagliptin, and simvastatin. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 136/82 mm Hg. A mechanical click is heard at the right upper sternal border.  Prothrombin time is 30 seconds (INR = 2.5). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer oral amoxicillin 1 hour before the procedure
Avoid nitrous oxide during the procedure
Discontinue aspirin and warfarin 72 hours prior to procedure
Administer oral azithromycin 1 hour before and 2 hours after the procedure

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Antimicrobial prophylaxis for the prevention of IE is recommended for high-risk patients (e.g., patients with prosthetic heart valves, a history of IE, or an unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart defect) who undergo procedures that are likely to result in bacteremia with common pathogens of IE. These procedures include certain dental procedures (e.g., tooth extraction, routine dental cleaning), procedures of the respiratory tract that involve incision of the respiratory mucosa, and cardiac surgery with prosthetic material (e.g., prosthetic heart valves). The most commonly used antibiotic regimen is oral amoxicillin administered 30–60 minutes prior to a high-risk procedure. Alternatives to amoxicillin include intravenous ampicillin in patients unable to take oral medication and azithromycin in patients allergic to penicillin.

B) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography is indicated in patients with prosthetic heart valves if a change in clinical symptoms (e.g, a new murmur, new cardiac symptoms) occurs or if valve dysfunction is suspected. Echocardiography is not routinely performed before dental procedures.

C) INCORRECT:

Nitrous oxide (NO) is a general anesthetic used for sedation and analgesia during dental procedures. Contraindications for using NO include known hypersensitivity to NO, history of vitreoretinal surgery, and intraocular gas bubbles (a treatment for retinal detachment), none of which apply to this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulation with a therapeutic INR should be continued in patients with prosthetic heart valves who undergo procedures in which only minor bleeding is expected or bleeding can be easily controlled (e.g., dental procedures, minor dermatologic procedures).

E) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is used as a second-line agent for the prevention of IE in high-risk patients allergic to penicillin. However, this patient has no history of allergies. Moreover, antibiotic prophylaxis is not routinely administered following dental procedures.
questions.hint: Patients with prosthetic heart valves are at an increased risk for infective endocarditis (IE), particularly when undergoing dental procedures.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of low-grade fever and a nonproductive cough for the past 4 weeks. During this period, he has also had fatigue, myalgia, and difficulty breathing. Three months ago, he underwent an aortic prosthetic valve replacement due to high-grade aortic stenosis. The patient has a history of hypertension, asthma, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. A colonoscopy 2 years ago was normal. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. He has never used illicit drugs. Current medications include aspirin, warfarin, lisinopril, metformin, inhaled albuterol, and a multivitamin. The patient appears lethargic. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 140/60 mm Hg. Rales are heard on auscultation of the lungs. A grade 2/6, diastolic blowing murmur is heard over the left sternal border and radiates to the right sternal border. A photograph of his right index finger is shown. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 13,800/mm3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 48 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus gallolyticus can cause IE, typically in association with colorectal cancer. This patient has no history or clinical features that suggest colorectal carcinoma and his colonoscopy 2 years ago was normal. This patient has prosthetic valve IE, which is more likely to be caused by a different organism.

B) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae is a very rare cause of IE, although it is more commonly seen in patients with underlying conditions such as asthma and diabetes mellitus. This patient has prosthetic valve IE, which is more likely to be caused by a different organism.

C) CORRECT:

Coagulase-negative staphylococci (e.g, S. epidermidis), which have the ability to adhere to foreign bodies and form a biofilm, are a common cause of early-onset prosthetic valve IE (i.e., ≤ 12 months following surgery). IE due to S. epidermidis typically has an insidious onset with a subacute disease course, as seen here. Staphylococcus aureus, another leading cause of prosthetic valve IE, typically causes acute disease with high fever, and severe constitutional symptoms.

See “Characteristics of selected causes of infective endocarditis” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Enterococci (e.g., Enterococcus faecalis) are a relatively common cause of IE and are typically associated with urinary tract infections or genitourinary procedures. This patient has prosthetic valve IE, which is more likely to be caused by a different organism.

E) INCORRECT:

Viridans streptococci are the most common cause of subacute IE and generally affect individuals with preexisting damage to the heart valves, structural heart defects, or prosthetic valves. However, prosthetic valve IE due to infection with viridans streptococci typically occurs > 1 year after valve replacement (i.e., late-onset IE), whereas this patient presents 3 months following surgery (i.e., early-onset IE).

F) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pyogenes is a very rare cause of IE. In the setting of a newly implanted prosthetic valve, a different causal organism is much more likely.

G) INCORRECT:

Disseminated gonorrheal infection (DGI) due to Neisseria gonorrhoeae can cause endocarditis. However, this patient has no history of gonorrhea, nor does he have symptoms of DGI such as arthritis, meningitis, or a pustular rash.
questions.hint: In a patient who recently underwent aortic valve replacement, the combination of fever, cough, dyspnea, new heart murmur, subungual splinter hemorrhages, and increased inflammatory markers suggests early-onset prosthetic valve infective endocarditis (IE).

questions.text: Blood cultures are sent to the laboratory and antibiotic treatment is started. Blood cultures confirm infection with methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus epidermidis. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

choices.text: Oral penicillin V + gentamicin for 4 weeks
Intravenous nafcillin + rifampin for 6 weeks + gentamicin for 2 weeks
Intravenous gentamicin + penicillin G for 2 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral penicillin V is not used for the treatment of IE. Intravenous penicillins (e.g., oxacillin) in combination with gentamicin may be used in the treatment of native valve staphylococcal IE if the pathogen is susceptible to this regimen. For S. epidermidis prosthetic valve endocarditis, IV combination therapy for a longer period than 4 weeks is required.

B) INCORRECT:

The combination of intravenous (not oral) gentamicin and ceftriaxone can be used to treat native valve IE that is caused by a penicillin-susceptible pathogen and not associated with any complications (e.g., perivalvular abscess). Treatment of prosthetic valve IE consists of a different combination of antibiotics, and a 4-week course is not the recommended duration.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin is not suitable for the treatment of IE. IE usually initially requires IV antibiotic therapy. The only case in which oral cloxacillin can be used is for confirmed right-sided S. aureus endocarditis in an individual who injects drugs.

D) CORRECT:

Intravenous therapy with nafcillin and rifampin for at least 6 weeks in combination with gentamicin for 2 weeks is the treatment of choice for prosthetic valve IE due to methicillin-susceptible staphylococci. Treatment with gentamicin is restricted to 2 weeks because the risk of renal toxicity increases with duration of therapy. Prosthetic valve IE generally requires a longer duration than native valve IE.

Prosthetic valve IE caused by methicillin-resistant staphylococci should be treated with an intravenous combination of vancomycin, rifampin, and gentamicin.

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous gentamicin and penicillin G are effective in the treatment of native valve IE caused by penicillin-susceptible gram-positive cocci as long as there are no complications, such as perivalvular abscess. If the response to therapy is adequate (resolution of fever, chills), a 2-week course is sufficient. This combination therapy is not, however, suitable for the treatment of prosthetic valve endocarditis. Moreover, the recommended duration of therapy for prosthetic valve endocarditis is longer than 2 weeks.

F) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin is the initial empiric antibiotic of choice in IE until blood cultures and susceptibility testing are obtained. Vancomycin is also used as IV monotherapy in patients with native valve IE caused by methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus or methicillin resistant coagulase negative staphylococci. This patient has prosthetic valve IE caused by methicillin susceptible staphylocci, for which a different treatment regimen is indicated.
questions.hint: This patient with prosthetic valve infective endocarditis (IE) requires treatment with a prolonged course of antibiotics that do not have to cover methicillin-resistant strains.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man with HIV comes to the physician because of fever and night sweats over the past 15 days. During this period, he has also had headaches and generalized weakness. He has no cough or shortness of breath. He has hypertension controlled with lisinopril and is currently receiving triple antiretroviral therapy. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years and drinks one to two beers on weekends. He is a known user of intravenous drugs. His temperature is 39°C (102°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Examination shows several track marks on the forearms. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A holosystolic murmur that increases on inspiration is heard along the left lower sternal border. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 12,800/mm3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 52 mm/h. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 450/mm3. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?

choices.text: Painful nodules on pads of the fingers
Asymptomatic hemorrhages on palms and soles

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Septic pulmonary embolism is a common and severe complication of right-sided IE and is caused by bacterial thromboemboli that form on the affected heart valve and dislodge into the lung. Patients present with cough, pleuritic chest pain, and nodular pulmonary infiltrates. While tricuspid valve IE is rare, nonsterile injections (e.g., in individuals who use IV drugs) leading to bacteremia as well as indwelling intravascular devices increase the risk for this condition.

Peripheral disease manifestations (e.g., Roth spots, Janeway lesions, embolic arterial occlusion of the kidney, brain, and spleen) are not typically seen in right-sided IE.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (supine) of a 24-year-old patient with history of intravenous drug use and septic emboli

Numerous pulmonary nodules are present in both lungs (examples indicated by green overlay). Some nodules have lucent centers indicating cavitation (examples indicated by red overlay). Air-space opacities, which were better appreciated on a subsequent CT scan (not shown), obscure the margins of some nodules.
The cardiac silhouette appears prominent as a result of rotation of the patient to the left.

The differential diagnosis of causes of multiple cavitary lung nodules includes bacterial, tuberculous, fungal, and parasitic infections as well as several noninfectious causes (e.g., rheumatic diseases and malignancies).

Arrowheads: thoracic spine spinous processes; dashed lines: medial clavicles; yellow overlay: right central line

B) INCORRECT:

Painful nodules on the pads of the fingers (i.e., Osler nodes) as a result of circulating immune complex deposition in the skin are a relatively rare but highly suggestive finding of IE. When they are seen, peripheral manifestations such as Osler nodes are more likely in patients with left-sided rather than right-sided IE. Moreover, Osler nodes typically occur in protracted cases of IE; this patient presents with acute IE.
Image Description:

There are multiple raised nodular lesions on the palm and palmar aspects of the first and second digits. The lesions appear dark brown, indicating subcutaneous hemorrhages.

This is the typical appearance of Osler nodes.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemorrhages underneath the fingernails (i.e., splinter hemorrhages) are a common finding in IE and are caused by septic microemboli from infected heart valves. However, they are more often seen in patients with left-sided rather than right-sided IE.
Image Description:

The vertical hemorrhages (arrowheads) underneath this patient's fingernails are most commonly caused by trauma but can also occur as a result of immune complex deposition or microthrombosis in subacute, infective endocarditis, SLE, or rheumatoid arthritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute kidney injury (AKI) leading to hematuria is a possible complication of IE and can be caused by immune complex glomerulonephritis or septic embolization leading to renal artery occlusion. However, AKI is more commonly seen in patients with left-sided rather than right-sided IE.

E) INCORRECT:

Retinal hemorrhages with pale centers (i.e., Roth spots) are highly suggestive of IE. However, they are a rare finding and when they are seen, they are more commonly present in patients with left-sided rather than right-sided IE. Moreover, Roth spots typically occur in protracted cases of IE, while this patient presents with acute IE.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a left eye

There are multiple red, white-centered lesions, which reflect small retinal hemorrhages with central accumulation of leukocytes or fibrin thrombocyte emboli (examples indicated by arrowheads).

Although these findings were formerly considered to be associated almost exclusively with infective endocarditis, they may actually occur in a variety of conditions, including hypertensive, diabetic, and HIV-related retinopathy; leukemia; and intracranial hemorrhage.

Circle: optic disc; M= macula

F) INCORRECT:

Asymptomatic hemorrhages on the palms and soles in IE are also known as Janeway lesions and most commonly occur in left-sided IE, not right-sided IE.
Image Description:

Multiple erythematous macules are visible on the thenar eminence and the base of the thumb.

These Janeway lesions are typically caused by septic microembolisms secondary to infective endocarditis.
questions.hint: In an individual who injects drugs, the combination of fever, night sweats, weakness, increased inflammatory markers, and a heart murmur characteristic of tricuspid regurgitation suggests right-sided infective endocarditis (IE).

questions.text: Blood cultures are sent to the laboratory and intravenous antibiotic therapy is started. Transesophageal echocardiography shows a large, oscillating vegetation attached to the tricuspid valve and multiple small vegetations attached to the tips of the tricuspid valve leaflets. There is moderate tricuspid regurgitation. The left side of the heart shows no abnormalities and ejection fraction is normal. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Viridans streptococci such as S. sanguinis are a relatively common cause of right-sided IE. However, IE due to viridans streptococci typically has a subacute course characterized by an insidious onset, slow progression (weeks to months), and less severe symptoms than the ones seen here (e.g., low-grade fever). A different causative pathogen is more likely in this patient with acute IE and a history of IV drug use.

B) INCORRECT:

Enterococci (e.g., Enterococcus faecalis) is a relatively common cause of right-sided IE. However, IE due to enterococci typically has a subacute disease course and occurs following nosocomial urinary tract infections or manipulation of the genitourinary tract (e.g., cystoscopy). A different causative pathogen is more likely in this patient with acute IE and a history of IV drug use.

C) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus epidermidis typically causes IE in patients with venous catheters, prosthetic heart valves, or medical devices (e.g., pacemakers, ICDs), as well as in individuals who inject drugs. However, IE due to S. epidermidis typically has a subacute course characterized by an insidious onset, slow progression (weeks to months), and less severe symptoms than the ones seen here (e.g., low-grade fever). A different causative pathogen is more likely in this patient with acute IE and a history of IV drug use.

D) CORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of acute IE in almost all groups of patients, including individuals who inject drugs, and the most common cause of right-sided IE. Other notable causative pathogens of IE associated with IV drug use include Staphylococcus epidermidis and fungi (e.g., Candida spp.).

Subacute IE, which is characterized by an insidious onset (weeks to months) and less severe constitutional symptoms (e.g., low-grade fever), is most commonly caused by viridans streptococci.

E) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pyogenes is a very rare cause of IE. In a patient with acute IE and a history of IV drug use, another causative pathogen is much more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus gallolyticus can cause IE, typically in association with colorectal cancer. This patient has no history or clinical features that suggest colorectal carcinoma. Moreover, IE due to S. gallolyticus typically has a subacute disease course characterized by an insidious onset, slow progression (weeks to months), and less severe symptoms than the ones seen here (e.g., low-grade fever). A different causative pathogen is more likely in this patient with acute IE and a history of IV drug use.
questions.hint: This patient has acute infective endocarditis (IE), which is evidenced by severe constitutional symptoms with a rapid onset.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and shortness of breath with moderate exertion for the past 2 months. Over the past 10 days, he has had low-grade fevers and night sweats. He has no history of serious illness except for a bicuspid aortic valve diagnosed 5 years ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years and drinks 3–5 beers on social occasions. He does not use illicit drugs. The patient takes no medications. He appears weak. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 128/64 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard best at the right sternal border and second intercostal space. There are several hemorrhages underneath his fingernails on both hands and multiple tender, red nodules on his fingers. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

S. gallolyticus is an uncommon cause of IE and is usually associated with colonic malignancies. However, this patient has no clinical features of colon cancer (e.g., weight loss, GI bleeding, abdominal mass), which makes infection with S. gallolyticus unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

S. epidermidis typically causes subacute IE in patients with peripheral or central venous catheters, surgical implants, or medical devices (e.g., pacemakers, ICDs) by forming a biofilm over the implanted foreign material. This pathogen is also a common cause of IE in patients who have undergone prosthetic valve surgery. However, this patient has no risk factors associated with S. epidermidis, which makes infection with this pathogen unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

E. faecalis is a common cause of subacute IE and is often associated with nosocomial urinary tract infections (UTIs) and manipulation of the genitourinary tract (e.g., cystoscopy). This patient has no recent history of UTI or surgical procedures, which makes E. faecalis an unlikely cause of his condition.

D) CORRECT:

Viridans streptococci, such as S. sanguinis, are the most common cause of subacute IE in damaged native heart valves (e.g., bicuspid aortic valve). Because viridans streptococci are part of the normal oral flora and can be introduced into the blood following dental procedures, patients with certain types of congenital heart disease (e.g., unrepaired cyanotic heart defects) should receive antibiotic prophylaxis prior to invasive dental procedures.

See “Characteristics of selected causes of infective endocarditis” table.

E) INCORRECT:

S. pneumoniae is an uncommon cause of IE and is associated with cirrhosis and HIV infection. This patient has no risk factors for S. pneumoniae endocarditis, which makes it an unlikely causal organism.

F) INCORRECT:

S. aureus is the most common cause of IE in patients with native heart valves. However, IE due to S. aureus typically causes acute IE characterized by a rapid disease progression whereas this patient has had a subacute course with symptoms for 2 months. Moreover, this pathogen typically affects previously healthy valves.

G) INCORRECT:

Infection with S. pyogenes can lead to rheumatic fever (RF), which can also manifest with fatigue, low-grade fever, night sweats, shortness of breath, and a heart murmur. However, splinter hemorrhages and Osler nodes are not seen in RF. This patient has subacute IE, which is very rarely caused by S. pyogenes.

H) INCORRECT:

C. albicans can cause endocarditis in immunosuppressed individuals as well as in patients who are IV drugs users or have recently undergone cardiac surgery. This patient has none of these risk factors.
questions.hint: Insidious onset of fatigue, low-grade fever, night sweats, and shortness of breath in combination with a systolic heart murmur, splinter hemorrhages, and Osler nodes indicate subacute infective endocarditis (IE). This patient's congenital heart defect makes him particularly susceptible to infection with a certain pathogen.

questions.text: Blood cultures are sent to the laboratory and empiric treatment with intravenous vancomycin is started. Blood cultures grow gram-negative bacilli identified as Cardiobacterium hominis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Because HACEK organisms are increasingly resistant to ampicillin monotherapy, this antibiotic should only be used to treat infective endocarditis caused by these organisms if in vitro susceptibility has been proven.

B) CORRECT:

Third-generation cephalosporins, such as ceftriaxone, have a broad spectrum coverage against gram-negative bacteria and are the treatment of choice for infective endocarditis caused by HACEK organisms. Alternative treatment regimens include fourth-generation cephalosporins, fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin), or ampicillin if in vitro susceptibility has been proven.

C) INCORRECT:

Penicillin G can be used for targeted antibiotic therapy of infective endocarditis that is caused by gram-positive organisms such as viridans streptococci and enterococci. Penicillin G is ineffective against most gram-negative pathogens including HACEK organisms.

D) INCORRECT:

Cefazolin can be used to treat infective endocarditis caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, but it is not effective against HACEK organisms.

E) INCORRECT:

Gentamicin is effective against gram-negative bacteria including HACEK organisms. However, gentamicin is both nephrotoxic and ototoxic, and the risk of developing one or more of the side effects of gentamicin is considerably higher if used for longer than 2 weeks. Since antibiotic therapy would be indicated for a minimum duration of 4 weeks in the case of infective endocarditis caused by C. hominis, a different antibiotic regimen is preferred.

F) INCORRECT:

A combination of rifampin and vancomycin (in addition to gentamicin) is used to treat infective endocarditis (IE) caused by methicillin-resistant staphylococci in patients with prosthetic heart valves. This patient does not have a history of valve replacement, and the combination of rifampin and vancomycin is not a recommended regimen for the treatment of IE caused by HACEK organisms.

G) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin, which is often used for empirical therapy in infective endocarditis, is highly effective against a wide range of gram-positive organisms. However, this antibiotic is ineffective against gram-negative bacteria such as HACEK organisms.
questions.hint: Following identification of the causative pathogen on blood cultures, targeted antibiotic therapy should be employed to increase the efficacy of therapy and reduce the risk of side effects. HACEK organisms such as Cardiobacterium hominis are highly susceptible to a certain group of antibiotics.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 3-day history of face and foot swelling, dark urine, and a rash on her hands and feet. The mother reports that for the past 4 weeks, her daughter has been having intermittent low-grade fevers and seems less energetic than usual. She has a ventricular septum defect that was diagnosed at birth. The patient appears lethargic. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 34/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Examination shows small, nonblanching purple lesions on her palms and soles, and under the fingernails. There is edema of the eyelids and feet. Fundoscopic examination shows retinal hemorrhages. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.3 g/dL


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
61 mm/h


Leukocyte count
15,000/mm3



Platelet count
326,000/mm3



Urine



 Blood
4+


 Glucose
Negative


 Protein
1+


 Ketones
Negative


Transthoracic echocardiography shows a small outlet ventricular septum defect and mild right ventricular enlargement. There is no evidence of cardiac wall motion abnormalities or valvular heart disease on echocardiography. One set of blood cultures was obtained and grows Streptococcus sanguinis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This child fulfills 5 of the minor Duke criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis (IE): a predisposing heart abnormality (ventricular septal defect), fever ≥ 38°C (100.4°F), vascular phenomena (splinter hemorrhages, Janeway lesions), immunologic phenomena (glomerulonephritis manifesting with nephritic syndrome, Roth spots), and a positive blood culture for a microorganism consistent with infective endocarditis (≥ 2 positive cultures are required to qualify as a major criterion). Viridans streptococci like S. sanguinis typically cause subacute endocarditis with an insidious onset over weeks to months and are common endocarditis pathogens in children with structural heart defects.

B) INCORRECT:

Acute rheumatic fever (ARF) is a noninfectious inflammatory complication of group A streptococcus infection that typically develops 1–5 weeks after acute tonsillopharyngitis. ARF manifests with fever, fatigue, skin lesions, and signs of inflammation (e.g., elevated leukocyte count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate). This patient's blood cultures are positive for S. sanguinis, not S. pyogenes, and the purple macules on her hands and feet are not typical of erythema marginatum or the subcutaneous nodules seen in ARF. Furthermore, ARF does not cause glomerulonephritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a contagious illness caused by Coxsackievirus that can manifest with fever, malaise, and a rash on the hands and feet. However, HFMD does not cause glomerulonephritis or retinal hemorrhages. Additionally, the positive S. sanguinis blood culture makes HFMD an unlikely diagnosis in this child.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can manifest with fever, fatigue, features of glomerulonephritis, skin lesions, and cardiac involvement (e.g., Libman-Sacks endocarditis). Libman-Sacks endocarditis can lead to systemic emboli that result in hemorrhages under the nails, skin, and retina. However, juvenile-onset SLE is uncommon, and this patient's positive blood cultures and an underlying heart defect indicate an infection rather than an autoimmune disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Kawasaki disease typically manifests with fever > 5 days, bilateral nonpurulent conjunctivitis, mucositis, cervical lymphadenopathy, and a diffuse erythematous rash over the palms and soles. Although this child has had a fever > 5 days, she does not have any other features of Kawasaki disease. Retinal hemorrhages, glomerulonephritis, and positive blood cultures are not expected with Kawasaki disease.
questions.hint: Children with congenital heart disease are at increased risk of developing this condition.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of fever, chills, and generalized weakness. He has no cough. He was treated for a neck abscess 6 months ago. He takes no medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years and drinks two to three beers daily. He has been using intravenous cocaine and heroin for 6 years. He appears ill. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows track marks on both cubital fossae. There are retinal hemorrhages with pale centers. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard best at the lower left sternal border. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.3 g/dL


Leukocyte count
14,300/mm3



Platelet count
278,000/mm3



Serum



 Glucose
96 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL


 Total bilirubin
0.4 mg/dL

18 U/L

Transthoracic echocardiography shows multiple vegetations on the tricuspid valve and moderate tricuspid regurgitation. Three sets of blood cultures are collected. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transesophageal echocardiography may be conducted for suspected IE if transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) findings are inconclusive (since TEE has a higher sensitivity (> 90%), or for a more detailed evaluation. Because vegetations have already been found with TTE, though, this patient does not need further echocardiographic evaluation at the moment.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous nafcillin therapy for 2 weeks is the treatment of choice for IE in intravenous drugs users who have confirmed infection with MSSA. However, while awaiting blood cultures to confirm the causative pathogen, this patient should be treated empirically with a different medication that also covers MRSA.

C) CORRECT:

Intravenous vancomycin therapy is the initial empiric antibiotic treatment in patients with native heart valves and suspected IE because its coverage includes MRSA. Empiric therapy is typically administered right after blood cultures are drawn.

The intravenous antibiotics should be adapted according to resistogram results from blood cultures. In intravenous drug users in which MRSA is not the causative pathogen, shorter 2-week antibiotic regimens with either intravenous nafcillin or oral cloxacillin can be considered.

D) INCORRECT:

An x-ray of the chest could be considered if septic pulmonary emboli are suspected. In that case, the x-ray might show solid and cavitary lesions. Although this patient presents with vegetations on the tricuspid valve from which septic pulmonary emboli could develop, he does not present with dyspnea. The underlying cause should first be addressed before considering additional testing.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with right-sided IE and is at risk of developing pulmonary embolism due to emboli resulting from the tricuspid valve vegetations. But he does not have any symptoms that suggest pulmonary involvement, such as dyspnea or an abnormal respiratory rate, meaning a CT pulmonary angiogram is not indicated at this time.

F) INCORRECT:

Intravenous ciprofloxacin therapy may be used to treat IE due to gram-negative HACEK group infections (e.g., Haemophilus species, Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans), but this patient requires empirical treatment with medications effective against Staphylococcus aureus, since S. aureus is the most common cause of acute IE for all patient groups.
questions.hint: This patient has definite acute infective endocarditis (IE) according to the Duke criteria, with 1 major criterion (valvular vegetations on echocardiography) and 3 minor criteria (fever, history of IV drug use, Roth spots) being fulfilled.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after an episode of loss of consciousness that lasted 3 minutes. Since awakening, he has had weakness of the left arm and leg, and his speech has been slurred. He has had a fever for 10 days. He has not had vomiting or headache. He was treated for bacterial sinusitis 3 weeks ago with amoxicillin-clavulanate. He has hypertension, hypothyroidism, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, metformin, simvastatin, aspirin, and levothyroxine. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.4°F), pulse is 106/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows multiple petechiae on his trunk and painless macules over both palms. A new grade 3/6 systolic murmur is heard best at the apex. He follows commands, but he slurs his words and has difficulty naming common objects. There is left facial droop. Muscle strength is 4/5 in the left upper and lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ on the left side and 2+ on the right side. The left big toe shows an extensor response. Fundoscopic examination shows retinal hemorrhages with white centers. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
15.3 g/dL


Leukocyte count
12,300/mm3



Serum



 Na+

136 mEq/L


 Cl-

103 mEq/L


 K+

4.3 mEq/L


 Glucose
108 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


Urine



 Protein
1+


 Glucose
negative


 Blood
1+


 WBC
1–2/hpf


 RBC

7–10/hpf


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Vasospasm of a deep penetrating artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Arteriovenous malformations (AVM) can arise anywhere in the body but can be particularly problematic in the central nervous system. AVMs are found in up to 20% of adults, though they manifest more often with recurrent seizures or cerebrovascular accident (either ischemic or, more commonly, hemorrhagic). In the case of a cerebrovascular accident, the presentation would be similar to what is described in this case. However, AVMs are symptomatic in less than 0.5% of the population and are most often diagnosed before a patient turns 40. Moreover, a ruptured AVM would not explain this patients fever, heart murmur, skin findings, or hematuria.

B) INCORRECT:

Saccular aneurysms are often unknown to the patient unless they are diagnosed incidentally or rupture and cause neurological symptoms. In the case of rupture, signs and symptoms of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) typically develop rapidly; thunderclap headache, nausea/vomiting, and rapid progression to coma and eventually death are common. This patient has no history of headache, nausea, or vomiting, which effectively rules out SAH. Moreover, it would not explain this patient's 10-day history of fever, new heart murmur, skin findings, or hematuria.

C) INCORRECT:

Todd's paralysis manifests with temporary unilateral weakness (usually of the arm and/or leg) following a seizure, which is sometimes accompanied by generalized aphasia. Patients in the postictal state are also commonly confused, disoriented, and/or somnolent. While this patient has unilateral weakness and confusion following a loss of consciousness, his aphasia is more characteristic of ischemia in the language center of the left temporal lobe rather than a seizure. Moreover, his loss of consciousness was not associated with automatisms or other signs of seizure (e.g., rhythmic jerking). Lastly, Todd's paralysis would not explain this patient's fever, new heart murmur, or skin abnormalities.

D) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex encephalitis (HSE) is typically characterized by a prodromal phase (e.g., fever, headache), followed by acute or subacute encephalopathy with focal neurological deficits, seizures, altered mental status, and behavioral changes. This patient also presents with fever, focal deficits, and encephalopathy. However, HSE would not explain this patient's heart murmur, skin findings, retinal hemorrhages, or kidney injury.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with signs and symptoms of acute infective endocarditis (IE), including fever, Janeway lesions, petechiae, a new heart murmur, hematuria (> 3 RBC on urinalysis) indicating renal injury, and Roth spots. Neurological complications of IE, such as ischemic stroke, intracerebral hemorrhage, and/or cerebral microabscesses, are often caused by septic emboli to the brain. Up to 40% of patients with IE experience symptomatic neurological complications, and up to 80% have embolic findings on brain imaging. This patient's extensive neurological findings indicate involvement of multiple brain areas.

Thrombolytic therapy is not recommended for patients with IE and embolic stroke because of the risk of cerebral hemorrhage. Empiric antibiotic treatment, which reduces the risk of recurrent embolism, should be initiated after collecting three sets of blood cultures. Moreover, evaluation of the brain with a noncontrast CT is indicated to rule out hemorrhage. Cardiothoracic surgery may be necessary for complicated IE.

F) INCORRECT:

Carotid artery stenosis is a common cause of CVA. This patient has multiple risk factors for carotid stenosis (e.g., hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus). However, stroke secondary to carotid stenosis would not explain his 10-day history of fever, the new heart murmur, skin findings, or hematuria.

G) INCORRECT:

Vasospasm of a deep penetrating artery would cause signs and symptoms of a lacunar stroke. Hypertension and diabetes mellitus are both substantial risk factors for a lacunar stroke. The most common lacunar stroke syndrome is a pure motor stroke, which manifests as isolated hemiparesis of the face, arm, or leg. Another common lacunar stroke syndrome is dysarthria-clumsy hand syndrome, which presents with dysarthria and unilateral hand weakness. While this patient is at high risk of lacunar stroke (HTN and DM), it would not explain his 2-week fever, new heart murmur, skin findings, or hematuria.

H) INCORRECT:

A cerebral abscess may result from the spread of an infection, such as recent bacterial sinusitis. Although a cerebral abscess can manifest with fever and focal neurological findings, the absence of headache and increased intracranial pressure make the diagnosis less likely. Furthermore, the patient has several additional symptoms (e.g., a heart murmur, skin manifestations, retinal hemorrhages, and kidney injury) that are not consistent with a cerebral abscess.
questions.hint: Acute unilateral limb weakness, unilateral hyperreflexia, positive Babinski sign, cranial nerve deficits (facial droop, dysarthria), and anomic aphasia (inability to name objects), indicate cerebrovascular accident (CVA). While this patient has multiple risk factors for CVA, his 10-day history of fever suggests an infectious cause.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency room because of a 5-day history of high fever and fatigue. During this time she has been crying more than usual and eating less. Her mother says that the child has also complained about pain in her arms and legs for the past 3 days. She was born at term and has been otherwise healthy. She appears ill. Her temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), pulse is 128/min, and blood pressure is 96/52 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 3/6 systolic murmur is heard at the apex. There is mild tenderness to palpation of the left upper quadrant with no guarding or rebound. The spleen is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin. There is no redness or swelling of the joints. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.8 g/dL


Leukocyte count
16,300/mm3


Platelet count
220,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
50 mm/h


Serum



 Glucose
96 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.7 mg/dL


 Total bilirubin
0.4 mg/dL


 AST
18 U/L


 ALT
20 U/L


Urine



 Protein

2+


 RBC casts
rare


 RBC

10/hpf


 WBC
1–2/hpf


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain three sets of blood cultures

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous vancomycin is the empiric treatment of choice for acute IE, as it is effective against the most common causative organisms (staphylococci and viridans streptococci). However, a different intervention should precede the start of empiric antibiotic therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

An antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is used as a screening test for several autoimmune diseases including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). SLE can manifest with fever, fatigue, arthralgia, splenomegaly, glomerulonephritis, and elevated ESR. A rare complication of SLE is Libman-Sacks endocarditis, which can manifest with a new-onset murmur. Instead of acute febrile disease, however, patients with SLE most commonly present with anorexia, fatigue, and a low-grade fever that is gradual in onset. Moreover, cytopenia with leukopenia rather than leukocytosis is seen in SLE. Finally, this condition is rare in children under the age of 5 years.

C) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid factor (RF) is a nonspecific inflammatory marker that may be elevated in patients with autoimmune or infectious diseases. Although RF is part of the minor diagnostic criteria of IE indicating immunologic phenomena, another, more appropriate step, must first be taken.

D) CORRECT:

In a patient with suspected IE, a minimum of three blood cultures from different venipuncture sites should be obtained as soon as possible and over a short period of time (e.g., < 1 hour in acutely ill patients). The presence of bacteria typical for IE (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus) obtained from two separate blood cultures is a major Duke criterion. Because patients with IE usually have continuous bacteremia, blood cultures are positive in a high percentage of cases. Blood cultures should always be collected before initiating antibiotic therapy, so as to avoid potentially false-negative results.

E) INCORRECT:

Transesophageal echocardiography is used to evaluate evidence of endocardial involvement (e.g., vegetation, abscess, regurgitation, dehiscence of a prosthetic valve), which is one of the two major Duke criteria used to establish a diagnosis of infective endocarditis. However, another, more appropriate step, must first be taken in this patient. In addition, transthoracic echocardiography is typically performed first, since it is a much less invasive test.

F) INCORRECT:

Renal biopsy may be necessary in patients with glomerulonephritis (GN) without an apparent cause or in the case of suspected rapidly progressive GN. This patient's GN occurred in the setting of acute IE; a renal biopsy is not indicated at this point.
questions.hint: This previously healthy child presents with high fever, arthralgia, a new-onset murmur, and splenomegaly. In combination with leukocytosis, an elevated ESR, and signs of glomerulonephritis (elevated creatinine, RBCs, and mild proteinuria on urinalysis), these findings suggest acute infective endocarditis (IE).

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of confusion and rapidly progressive dyspnea. He has had a fever and chills for the past five days. Five years ago, he was diagnosed with hepatitis C. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 15 years and drinks one to two beers daily. He has a history of past intravenous heroin use. He appears pale, anxious, and in severe distress. His temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), respirations are 30/min, pulse is 59/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 75%. Examination shows multiple linear hemorrhages underneath the nails. There are nontender maculae on both palms and soles. Fine rales are heard bilaterally on auscultation of the chest. Cardiac examination shows an S3; a grade 3/6 high-pitched decrescendo early diastolic murmur is heard along the left sternal border and right second intercostal space. An x-ray of the chest shows a normal-sized heart and pulmonary edema. An ECG shows P waves and QRS complexes that occur at regular intervals, but independently of each other. Transesophageal echocardiography of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: A highly echogenic, thin, linear structure in the right atrium
Heterogeneous mass attached to the interatrial septum
Anechoic space between pericardium and epicardium
Perivalvular thickening with an echolucent cavity
Oscillating mobile mass on the tricuspid valve
Eccentric hypertrophy of the left ventricle

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A highly echogenic, thin, linear structure in the right atrium indicates a pacemaker or implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD). This patient neither has a history of cardiac disease (e.g., arrhythmias) nor a history of ICD placement.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac myxoma is the most common primary tumor of the heart in adults and usually presents with an early diastolic sound. Patients may also have constitutional symptoms (fever, weight loss, night sweats) and repeated syncopal episodes. Although this patient has an early diastolic murmur and fever, he has not had syncope, weight loss, or night sweats. Additionally, he has specific findings (splinter hemorrhages, Janeway lesions) indicating IE rather than cardiac myxoma.

C) INCORRECT:

An anechoic space between the pericardium and epicardium is seen in patients with cardiac tamponade. Patients with cardiac tamponade typically present with hypotension, muffled heart sounds, distended neck veins, tachycardia, pulsus paradoxus, and electrical alternans on the ECG.

D) CORRECT:

Perivalvular thickening with an echolucent cavity indicates perivalvular abscess formation, a severe complication of IE that develops when infection spreads to the valve annulus and/or cardiac septum. Conduction abnormalities on ECG (e.g., AV block) occur when the abscess extends to cardiac conduction tissues, and they are most commonly seen in patients with aortic valve involvement. Perivalvular abscess is associated with high mortality if left untreated, as well as additional complications such as systemic embolization and acute coronary syndrome (due to coronary compression).

Always suspect a perivalvular abscess in patients with IE who develop a new conduction abnormality.
Image Description:

Echocardiography (transesophageal; biplane mid-esophageal) of patient with aortic valve bioprosthesis, fever, chest discomfort, and increasing shortness of breath

A mobile hyperechoic mass on the aortic valve (arrow) is suspicious for infectious endocarditis. Additional hyperechoic perivalvular thickening (arrowhead) suggests the presence of a valve ring abscess.

Ao: aorta; IAS: interatrial septum; LA: left atrium; LV: left ventricle; MV: mitral valve; RA: right atrium; RV: right ventricle; TV: tricuspid valve

E) INCORRECT:

An oscillating mobile mass on the tricuspid valve would be seen in patients with IE that affects the tricuspid valve. Right-sided IE usually occurs in individuals who inject drugs. However, right-sided valvular lesions rarely lead to conduction abnormalities. Instead, conduction abnormalities are usually associated with IE of the aortic valve, which is consistent with this patient's auscultatory findings.

F) INCORRECT:

Eccentric hypertrophy of the left ventricle (LV) is typically seen in chronic aortic regurgitation. Although this patient presents with acute aortic regurgitation, he is unlikely to have eccentric hypertrophy since the aortic regurgitation is new-onset. ECG findings in patients with LV hypertrophy include left axis deviation and a positive Sokolow-Lyon index, but this patient's ECG shows a third-degree atrioventricular block. Although this patient may develop eccentric hypertrophy as a complication if he is not properly treated, it is unlikely at this time.
questions.hint: The combination of fever, splinter hemorrhages, Janeway lesions, and a heart murmur characteristic of aortic regurgitation suggests infective endocarditis (IE). Rapidly progressive dyspnea, bilateral rales on auscultation, pulmonary edema, hypotension, and hypoxia are consistent with acute heart failure. ECG findings show a third-degree atrioventricular (AV) block.

questions.text: Six days after being admitted to the hospital for cholecystectomy, a 56-year-old woman has high-grade fevers, chills, malaise, and generalized weakness. She has been hospitalized twice in the last year for acute cholecystitis. She had a molar extraction around 2 weeks ago. Her last colonoscopy was 8 months ago and showed a benign polyp that was removed. She has mitral valve prolapse, hypertension, rheumatoid arthritis, and hypothyroidism. Current medications include metformin, rituximab, levothyroxine, and enalapril. Her temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 138/90 mm Hg. Examination shows painless macules over her palms and soles and linear hemorrhages under her nail beds. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is a grade 3/6 systolic murmur heard best at the apex. Blood is drawn and she is started on intravenous antibiotic therapy. Two sets of blood cultures grow coagulase-negative staphylococci. Echocardiography shows a large oscillating vegetation on the mitral valve and moderate mitral regurgitation. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Individuals with predamaged heart valves (e.g., mitral valve prolapse) are at increased risk for developing IE. However, the organisms most commonly associated with IE in predamaged valves are viridans streptococci, which are gram-positive streptococci. Viridans streptococci typically cause subacute IE, which is characterized by a slow progression (weeks to months) and less severe constitutional symptoms (e.g., low fever may occur but is often absent).

B) INCORRECT:

A colonic polyp may be benign or malignant. Malignant colonic polyps can develop into colon cancer. IE due to an infection with Streptococcus gallolyticus (formerly known as Streptococcus bovis biotype I, a group D Streptococci) is associated with an increased incidence of colonic neoplasms. However, this patient had coagulase-negative staphylococci in her blood cultures and a colonoscopy 8 months ago showed a benign polyp, all of which make this risk factor unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Dental procedures are an important risk factor for subacute IE, especially in patients with predamaged native valves (mainly the mitral valve) and in patients with prosthetic valves (≥ 60 days after surgery). The most common pathogens in subacute IE are viridans streptococci (gram-positive streptococci), a common commensal of the oropharynx. Subacute IE has an insidious onset, is characterized by slow progression (weeks to months), and has less severe constitutional symptoms (e.g., low fever may occur but is often absent). Although this patient has a history of a predamaged native valve (mitral valve prolapse), she presents with acute IE and has severe symptoms, which make the diagnosis of subacute IE due to an infection with viridans streptococci unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Immunosuppression is an important risk factor for IE, particularly with atypical pathogens such as Candida species and Aspergillus fumigatus. This patient takes rituximab, which is in fact considered an immunosuppressive medication. IE caused by Candida species and Aspergillus fumigatus occurs especially following cardiosurgical interventions. However, infection with coagulase-negative staphylococci, as in this patient, is more often associated with a different risk factor than immunosuppression.

E) CORRECT:

This patient with acute IE has most likely acquired S. epidermidis bacteremia through an infected peripheral venous catheter during her hospital stay. S. epidermidis has the ability to adhere to foreign bodies (e.g., intravenous catheters, pacemakers) and subsequently form a biofilm. The pathogen accounts for about 30% of health care-associated bloodstream infections and is a common cause of IE in patients with prosthetic heart valves (see “Pathogens causing infective endocarditis” table).

Because coagulase-negative staphylococci often colonize the skin of healthy individuals, they are commonly found in contaminated blood cultures, and their presence is not always clinically significant. Repeat cultures and evaluation of the culture results in accordance with clinical findings are therefore recommended.
questions.hint: Acute onset of high-grade fever, chills, splinter hemorrhages, and Janeway lesions (painless macules on palms and soles) in combination with a valvular vegetation on echocardiography and two positive blood cultures suggest acute infective endocarditis (IE). The coagulase-negative Staphylococcus species most commonly associated with IE is Staphylococcus epidermidis.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-week history of increasing weakness and chills. She also notes difficulty breathing for the last 3 days. Eight weeks ago, she underwent a left hemicolectomy for adenocarcinoma of the colon. She subsequently developed a severe urinary tract infection, was treated in the intensive care unit for 4 days, and was discharged from the hospital 3 weeks ago. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, osteoporosis with lumbar pain, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. She does not drink alcohol and has never used illicit drugs. Current medications include warfarin, metformin, lisinopril, and aspirin. She appears lethargic and has a large conjunctival hemorrhage in her left eye. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 126/79 mm Hg. Cardiac auscultation reveals a new holosystolic murmur over the apex. Abdominal examination shows mild, diffuse tenderness throughout the upper quadrants and a well-healed 12-cm paramedian scar. There are multiple tender nodules on the palmar surface of her fingertips. Fundoscopic examination shows retinal hemorrhages with pale centers. An ECG shows atrial fibrillation and right bundle branch block. Which of the following is the most likely underlying etiology of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary metastases from her colorectal cancer could explain this patient's difficulty breathing. Carcinomas of the lower rectum are known to metastasize to the lungs and her history of colon cancer should raise concern. However, pulmonary metastatic disease would not explain her fever, new murmur, Osler nodes, or Roth spots.

B) INCORRECT:

Viridans streptococci such as Streptococcus sanguinis are the most common cause of subacute IE, especially in compromised native valves and prosthetic valves. IE caused by viridans streptococci is associated with dental procedures, as these organisms are a normal part of the oral flora. Although IE due to S. sanguinis would fit this patient's timeline, she has no prior history of valvular disease and has not undergone any recent dental work.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiobacterium hominis belongs to the group of HACEK organisms, a group of fastidious gram-negative bacilli that were previously difficult to isolate on routine blood cultures. HACEK organisms are only responsible for about 3% of IE cases and are now more readily identified with the use of automated blood culture systems. While IE with a HACEK organism could certainly cause a similar presentation, this patient's history makes an alternative etiology more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) is a rare form of noninfectious endocarditis that is characterized by sterile thrombi deposition on the heart valves. NBTE is associated with malignancy and certain autoimmune conditions (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, SLE), and most commonly affects the aortic and mitral valves. Patients are usually asymptomatic until there is evidence of thromboembolic phenomena. This patient's history of colon cancer and new murmur could be consistent with NBTE; however, fever and other systemic symptoms would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

IE is rarely caused by a fungal infection, with Aspergillus fumigatus accounting for approximately one-third of all cases. The vast majority of Aspergillus endocarditis cases occur among patients with prosthetic valves, those who have undergone cardiosurgical interventions, or those who are significantly immunocompromised. Given this patient's history, a different etiology is more likely.

F) CORRECT:

Enterococci are a common cause of IE following nosocomial UTIs. E. faecalis is especially virulent and is more likely than E. faecium to progress to bacteremia and endocarditis. Because penicillin resistance varies within the group of enterococci, combination therapy (e.g., ampicillin plus gentamicin) is recommended in the treatment of enterococcal endocarditis.

See “Characteristics of selected causes of infective endocarditis” table.
questions.hint: This patient has definite subacute infective endocarditis (IE) according to the Duke criteria: she fulfills 1 major criterion (new valvular regurgitation on auscultation) and 3 minor criteria (fever, vascular abnormalities (conjunctival hemorrhage), and immunologic manifestations (Osler nodes, Roth spots). Her history of a nosocomial urinary tract infection (UTI) indicates infection with a certain pathogen.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 6-day history of fever and chills. During this period, he has had generalized weakness, chest pain, and night sweats. He has a bicuspid aortic valve and recurrent migraine attacks.  He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years. He does not drink alcohol. He has experimented with intravenous drugs in the past but has not used any illicit drugs in the last 2 months. Current medications include propranolol and a multivitamin. He appears ill. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 150/50 mm Hg. On pulmonary examination, diffuse crackles are heard. A grade 3/6 high-pitched, early diastolic, decrescendo murmur is best heard along the left sternal border. An S3 gallop is heard. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
13,300/mm3



Platelet count
270,000/mm3



Serum



 Glucose
92 mg/dL


 Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL


 Total bilirubin
0.4 mg/dL


 AST
25 U/L


 ALT
28 U/L


Three sets of blood cultures are sent to the laboratory. Transthoracic echocardiography confirms the diagnosis. In addition to antibiotic therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Mechanical valve replacement of the tricuspid valve
Mechanical valve replacement of the aortic valve
Porcine valve replacement of the aortic valve
Surgical repair of the mitral valve

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mechanical valve replacement of the tricuspid valve is indicated for IE of the tricuspid valve causing congestive heart failure. However, tricuspid valve endocarditis would lead to right-sided heart failure, leading to distention of the neck veins and lower extremity edema. Additionally, this patient's murmur, widened pulse pressure, and acute left-sided heart failure are suggestive of aortic valve endocarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Because the patient has an acute, life-threatening illness, urgent intervention is required. After acute intervention, echocardiography is indicated before discharge and in subsequent follow-ups.

C) CORRECT:

The patient has acute aortic regurgitation and subsequent left-sided heart failure from IE, which together are an indication for surgical intervention. Further indications for surgical treatment of IE include uncontrolled infection, systemic embolization, prosthetic valve endocarditis, or fungal endocarditis. Mechanical valve replacement is the treatment of choice in a young (< 65 years of age) patient without contraindications for anticoagulation. Patients with current bleeding, history of intracranial hemorrhage, coagulopathy, or severe thrombocytopenia (< 50,000/μL) should be evaluated for porcine valve replacement as mechanical valves require lifelong anticoagulation.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

D) INCORRECT:

Porcine valves are less durable than mechanical valves and have a 60–70% failure rate at 20 years if implanted in patients younger than 65 years of age. For this reason, porcine valve replacement is preferred in older patients (> 65 years) or in patients with contraindications to anticoagulation (e.g., bleeding, coagulopathy, severe thrombocytopenia). Since this patient is 25 years of age and has no such contraindications, a porcine valve is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiac MRI can provide high-quality images of the heart but is not always available and takes more time than other imaging modalities. As the diagnosis of acute aortic regurgitation is unambiguous, has been confirmed by echocardiography in this patient, and urgent intervention is required, cardiac MRI is not indicated.

F) INCORRECT:

Surgical repair of the mitral valve is indicated for IE of the mitral valve causing heart failure. This patient's early diastolic murmur heard best along the left sternal border and widened pulse pressure are consistent with aortic regurgitation, though, not a mitral valve pathology.

Endocarditis of the mitral valve can cause mitral stenosis, which can also lead to left-sided heart failure. Mitral stenosis presents with a delayed diastolic murmur with a decrescendo, but it is best heard at the heart apex and does not lead to a widened pulse pressure.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

G) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization would be appropriate in patients who are undergoing workup for acute coronary syndrome. This patient has IE and acute left-sided heart failure, which necessitates another intervention.

H) INCORRECT:

Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI) is indicated in patients who require aortic valve replacement but are poor surgical candidates for open repair. As it is indicated for patients with severe aortic stenosis, it would not be useful for this patient's acute aortic regurgitation. Additionally, active IE is an absolute contraindication for TAVI.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.
questions.hint: This patient with a history of bicuspid aortic valve and IV drug use presents with infective endocarditis (IE). The widened pulse pressure and early diastolic murmur along the left sternal border suggest acute aortic regurgitation as a complication, with the S3 gallop and pulmonary edema indicating left-sided heart failure.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of shortness of breath, fever, and chills. He has no history of serious illness. His temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F). Physical examination shows a grade 4/6, holosystolic, blowing murmur over the apex that radiates to the axilla. Crackles are heard in both lower lung fields. Examination of the extremities shows several nontender, nonblanching, erythematous macules on the palms and soles. Histopathologic examination of these macules is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Capillary wall rupture with fibrin thrombus formation
Microabscesses with neutrophil infiltration of capillaries
Epithelioid cells with surrounding multinucleated giant cells
Spiral-shaped bacteria with axial filaments in the epidermis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Roth spots are the fundoscopic finding of white-centered retinal hemorrhages that are characterized histologically by microthrombi that form at the site of retinal capillary damage. They can be seen with infective endocarditis, as well as with leukemia, anoxic brain injury, carbon monoxide poisoning, and HIV. In contrast, Janeway lesions do not affect the eye and hemorrhage is not believed to be a primary component of Janeway lesions.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a left eye

There are multiple red, white-centered lesions, which reflect small retinal hemorrhages with central accumulation of leukocytes or fibrin thrombocyte emboli (examples indicated by arrowheads).

Although these findings were formerly considered to be associated almost exclusively with infective endocarditis, they may actually occur in a variety of conditions, including hypertensive, diabetic, and HIV-related retinopathy; leukemia; and intracranial hemorrhage.

Circle: optic disc; M= macula

B) CORRECT:

Microabscesses with neutrophil infiltration of capillaries and areas of hemorrhage are characteristic of the Janeway lesions seen in patients with infective endocarditis. They are thought to be caused by septic microemboli from valve vegetations and, among other vascular phenomena, constitute a minor clinical criterion for the Duke criteria in infective endocarditis. Janeway lesions are more common in acute endocarditis than in subacute endocarditis.

C) INCORRECT:

Epitheloid cells with surrounding multinucleated giant cells are characteristic of granulomatous inflammation, which is associated with numerous conditions, including tuberculosis, systemic fungal infection, sarcoidosis, and granulomatosis with polyangiitis. However, none of these conditions present with high fever and a new-onset heart murmur. Janeway lesions are not caused by granulomatous inflammation.

D) INCORRECT:

Cleft-like vacuoles within arterioles are the histological hallmark of cholesterol embolism. The most common skin manifestations of cholesterol embolization include livedo reticularis, gangrene, cyanosis, skin ulcer, purpura or petechiae, and firm, painful erythematous nodules. Janeway lesions have a different appearance on histology than cholesterol emboli.

The vacuole appearance of cholesterol embolism occurs due to cholesterol dissolution when exposed to tissue fixation.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of renal tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

Spindle-shaped, white spaces (yellow overlay) can be seen in an arterial vessel (dashed outline). These spaces (cholesterol clefts) are formed when the fat molecules in cholesterol emboli dissolve during sample processing.

E) INCORRECT:

Spiral-shaped bacteria with axial filaments on microscopic examination of a specimen would be consistent with secondary syphilis, which is caused by an infection with the spirochete Treponema pallidum. Patients with secondary syphilis present with a disseminated, maculopapular rash involving the entire trunk and extremities (including the palms and soles). However, this patient does not have any other clinical features of secondary syphilis, such as generalized lymphadenopathy, myalgia, or condylomata lata.
questions.hint: This patient presents with high fever, dyspnea, and a mitral regurgitation murmur, which suggests acute infective endocarditis of the mitral valve, complicated by pulmonary edema. The nontender, erythematous macules on the palms and soles of this man are most likely Janeway lesions.

questions.text: An autopsy of a patient's heart who recently died in a motor vehicle accident shows multiple nodules near the line of closure on the ventricular side of the mitral valve leaflet. Microscopic examination shows that these nodules are composed of immune complexes, mononuclear cells, and thrombi interwoven with fibrin strands. These nodules are most likely to be found in which of the following patients?

choices.text: A 54-year-old male who recently underwent dental surgery
A 71-year-old male with acute-onset high fever and nail bed hemorrhages
A 41-year-old female with a facial rash and nonerosive arthritis
A 28-year-old HIV-positive female intravenous drug user
A 62-year-old male with Cardiobacterium hominis bacteremia
A 6-year-old female with subcutaneous nodules and erythema marginatum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with congenital heart defects or prosthetic heart valves are prone to S. viridans bacteremia after dental surgery. S. viridans is the most common cause of subacute infectious endocarditis. Viridans streptococci typically infect platelet-fibrin aggregates on heart valves with pre-existing damage. The microscopic exam in this deceased patient showed no evidence of bacteria, which rules out infectious endocarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Splinter hemorrhages in the setting of high fever are suspicious for acute infectious endocarditis. S. aureus is the most common cause of acute infectious endocarditis, which often affects previously normal valves. Unlike the nonbacterial thrombi found on autopsy, infectious endocarditis would show bacteria on microscopic examination.

C) CORRECT:

A facial rash and symmetric, nonerosive polyarthritis in a middle-aged female is highly suspicious for systemic lupus erythematosus. Systemic inflammation in SLE can lead to the deposition of circulating sterile immune complexes with platelet thrombi on either side of valve leaflets in what is known as Libman-Sacks endocarditis. Although the vegetations seen in Libman-Sacks endocarditis are usually asymptomatic, they are easily dislodged and can embolize, causing complications. Valvular damage is rare but can sometimes manifest as mitral regurgitation or mitral stenosis.

Other diseases with systemic inflammation, such as advanced cancer or rheumatoid arthritis, can also precipitate Libman-Sacks endocarditis.

D) INCORRECT:

Injection drug use puts patients at high risk for infectious endocarditis and HIV-positive individuals are especially susceptible. The most common causal pathogen is S. aureus. However, infectious endocarditis in intravenous drug users most often involves the tricuspid valve instead of the mitral valve, as seen here. Furthermore, the microscopic exam in this deceased patient would have shown evidence of bacteria rather than nonbacterial thrombi.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiobacterium hominis belongs to the HACEK organisms, a class of bacteria that cause infectious endocarditis. These organisms require longer times to grow in culture and can even result in negative cultures. Infectious endocarditis would present with bacteria on microscopic examination, as opposed to the nonbacterial (i.e., sterile) thrombi found on autopsy here.

F) INCORRECT:

Subcutaneous nodules and erythema marginatum are manifestations of acute rheumatic fever, which results from the formation of autoantibodies after untreated group A streptococcus tonsillopharyngitis. Unlike the isolated endocarditis found on autopsy, the nonspecific carditis seen in acute rheumatic fever tends to involve the pericardium, epicardium, myocardium, and endocardium. Acute rheumatic fever is caused by a type II hypersensitivity reaction, whereas the immune complex deposits seen on this patient's autopsy are indicative of a type III hypersensitivity reaction. Also, microscopic examination would show myocardial granulomas (Aschoff bodies) and Anitschkow cells.

Rheumatic heart disease can rarely cause nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis but only after years of disease. This 6-year-old presents with early symptoms of acute rheumatic fever, and therefore, would not have such lesions.
questions.hint: Nonbacterial verrucous thrombi on the undersurface of the mitral valve are suggestive of Libman-Sacks endocarditis.

questions.text: Three weeks after undergoing transurethral prostate resection for benign prostatic hyperplasia, a 70-year-old man has fever, malaise, and pain in his extremities. Physical examination shows subungual petechiae and tender red papules on his fingers and toes. A new holosystolic murmur is heard on chest auscultation. A photomicrograph of a Gram stain of an isolate from blood culture is shown. The organism does not cause hemolysis on blood agar. Addition of pyrrolidonyl-β-naphthylamide gives the bacterial colonies a cherry red color. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive coccus and the most common causative agent for acute infective endocarditis. However, S. aureus is typically β-hemolytic and PYR-negative unlike the γ-hemolytic, PYR-positive organisms seen here.

B) CORRECT:

Enterococcus faecalis is a gram-positive, PYR positive, catalase-negative coccus that can grow in 6.5% NaCl and produces variable hemolysis (α-hemolytic or γ-hemolytic) on blood agar. It can cause subacute infective endocarditis in patients who undergo gastrointestinal or genitourinary procedures (e.g., transurethral prostate resection). Enterococcus spp. are resistant to drugs typically used to treat infective endocarditis such as penicillin G, 1st to 4th generation cephalosporins, and vancomycin (in the case of VRE). Enterococcus is sensitive to aminopenicillins and 5th generation cephalosporins (e.g., ceftaroline).

C) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative β-hemolytic PYR-negative bacillus that has been associated with infective endocarditis in patients with IV drug use (IVDU). This patient has no history of IVDU, and the presence of gram-positive, γ-hemolytic, PYR-positive bacteria makes pseudomonal endocarditis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:
