Streptococcus mutans (a type of viridans streptococci) is a gram-positive coccus that can cause infective endocarditis. However, Streptococcus mutans is α-hemolytic, unlike the γ-hemolytic organisms seen here, and it typically causes endocarditis in patients with previously damaged heart valves who undergo a dental procedure, unlike this patient who develops endocarditis after undergoing a genitourinary procedure.

E) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus gallolyticus is a γ-hemolytic, gram-positive coccus that can cause endocarditis. However, S. gallolyticus would show a negative PYR test, and it typically causes endocarditis in patients with colon cancer or in patients who undergo GI procedures (e.g., colon surgery), unlike this patient who develops endocarditis after undergoing a genitourinary procedure.

F) INCORRECT:

Cardiobacterium hominis belongs to the HACEK group of organisms, which can cause infective endocarditis. However, HACEK organisms are fastidious (i.e., cannot be cultured), and Cardiobacterium hominis is a gram-negative coccobacillus, unlike the gram-positive organisms here.

G) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus epidermidis is a γ-hemolytic, gram-positive coccus that can cause endocarditis. However, S. epidermidis would show a negative PYR test, and it typically causes endocarditis in patients with prosthetic heart valves, unlike this patient who develops endocarditis after undergoing a genitourinary procedure.
questions.hint: Presence of a new holosystolic murmur, Osler nodes, and splinter hemorrhages is suggestive of infective endocarditis. Photomicrograph and blood agar culture reveal gram-positive cocci that are γ-hemolytic and PYR-positive.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with ovarian cancer comes to the physician with a 5-day history of fever, chills, and dyspnea. She has a right subclavian chemoport in which she last received chemotherapy 2 weeks ago. Her temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 115/min. Cardiopulmonary examination shows jugular venous distention and a new, soft holosystolic murmur heard best in the left parasternal region. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. Echocardiography shows a vegetation on the tricuspid valve. Peripheral blood cultures taken from this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Gram-positive, catalase-negative, α-hemolytic, optochin-resistant cocci in chains
Gram-positive, catalase-positive, coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant cocci in clusters
Gram-positive, catalase-positive, coagulase-positive cocci in clusters
Gram-positive, catalase-negative, nonhemolytic, salt-sensitive cocci in chains
Gram-positive, catalase-negative, β-hemolytic, bacitracin-resistant cocci in chains

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The above microbiologic findings would indicate Viridans streptococci infection. However, these bacteria usually cause infection following dental procedures and afflict previously damaged native valves or prosthetic valves, neither of which are present in this patient. Moreover, Viridans streptococci typically cause subacute infection, whereas this patient presents with a 5-day history.

B) INCORRECT:

The above microbiologic findings would indicate Staphylococcus saprophyticus infection. This pathogen typically causes urinary tract infections rather than endocarditis.

Staphylococcus epidermidis, a bacterium commonly causing line-associated endocarditis, has similar microbiologic features but is novobiocin sensitive.

C) CORRECT:

The new holosystolic murmur in the left parasternal region and the echocardiographic findings indicate affliction of the tricuspid valve. Blood culture findings of gram-positive, catalase-positive, coagulase-positive cocci in clusters are characteristic of Staphylococcus aureus, which is the most common pathogen that causes acute infective endocarditis (including in patients with previously healthy valves).

In this clinical scenario, infection with Staphylococcus epidermidis would be a reasonable working diagnosis as well, especially since this bacterium is commonly responsible for infections via peripheral venous catheters. However, S. epidermidis is coagulase-negative.
Image Description:

Colorized scanning electron micrograph

S. aureus is spherical and forms grape-like clusters (the word Staphylococcus name derives from the Greek word "staphyle" = bunch of grapes). This characteristic distribution pattern arises because Staphylococci replicate randomly in all directions; the bacteria themselves are, however, immotile.

D) INCORRECT:

The above microbiologic findings would indicate Streptococcus gallolyticus infection. Infection with this bacterium is associated with colorectal cancer but not with ovarian cancer. Moreover, S. gallolyticus is only responsible for a small share of infective endocarditis cases and the gastrointestinal surface is a far more likely portal of entry than a central venous access.

E) INCORRECT:

The above microbiologic findings would indicate Streptococcus agalactiae infection. While this pathogen can cause respiratory symptoms in adults, it is usually responsible for neonatal infections (particularly neonatal meningitis). It is not associated with infective endocarditis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of infective endocarditis (2 major Duke criteria: a new valvular murmur, valvular vegetations on echocardiography). The chemoport is the most likely route of infection.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 10-day history of generalized weakness. He has also had headaches and night sweats and is a known user of illicit intravenous drugs. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 127/78 mm Hg. There are several track marks on his forearms. A holosystolic murmur that increases on inspiration is heard along the left sternal border. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 13,900/mm3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 58 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely consequence of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Painless macules and papules on palms and soles
Painful nodules on pads of the fingers

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hematuria is caused by a wide range of conditions, including trauma, infections, malignant tumors, and ischemia. Renal damage in IE is primarily caused by two mechanisms: Septic embolization can lead to renal artery occlusion with subsequent ischemia and renal damage, while immunoglobulin and complement deposition in the glomerulus can lead to glomerulonephritis. Although a septic embolism can cause renal injury in IE, this complication is more common in left-sided involvement.

B) INCORRECT:

In IE, painless macules and papules on the palms and soles are known as Janeway lesions. These occur more commonly in left-sided IE than right-sided IE.
Image Description:

Multiple erythematous macules are visible on the thenar eminence and the base of the thumb.

These Janeway lesions are typically caused by septic microembolisms secondary to infective endocarditis.

C) INCORRECT:

Splinter hemorrhages are caused by the rupture of capillaries in the nail bed and are seen in various conditions, including trauma, IE, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, and trichinosis. Patients with left-sided endocarditis are more likely to have splinter hemorrhages than those with right-sided endocarditis.
Image Description:

The vertical hemorrhages (arrowheads) underneath this patient's fingernails are most commonly caused by trauma but can also occur as a result of immune complex deposition or microthrombosis in subacute, infective endocarditis, SLE, or rheumatoid arthritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Retinal hemorrhages occur in a variety of diseases, including central retinal vein occlusion, malignant hypertension, retinal detachment, subarachnoid hemorrhage, and IE (where they are known as Roth spots). However, peripheral manifestations such as retinal hemorrhages are not commonly observed in patients with right-sided IE.

E) CORRECT:

IV drug users such as this patient are at increased risk of IE because the use of nonsterile syringes can lead to bacteremia. Bacterial colonization of the heart valves can lead to the formation of thrombi and subsequent bacterial emboli. While right heart involvement is rare in IE, IV drug users are at an increased risk of tricuspid or multiple valvular involvement. Thrombi from the right heart most frequently dislodge into the lung, which puts the patient at risk of pulmonary embolism. Patients with left-sided (aortic valve or mitral valve) endocarditis more commonly present with emboli to the retina (i.e., Roth spots), extremities (e.g., Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, splinter hemorrhages), kidney, brain, and spleen.

F) INCORRECT:

Painful nodules on the pads of the fingers (also known as Osler nodes), which are caused by the deposition of immune complexes in the skin, are a rare but highly suggestive finding in IE. However, peripheral manifestations such as Osler nodes are not commonly observed in patients with right-sided endocarditis. Moreover, Osler nodes typically occur in protracted cases of IE, whereas this patient presents with acute IE.
Image Description:

There are multiple raised nodular lesions on the palm and palmar aspects of the first and second digits. The lesions appear dark brown, indicating subcutaneous hemorrhages.

This is the typical appearance of Osler nodes.
questions.hint: The patient uses illicit IV drugs and presents with fever, tricuspid regurgitation, and leukocytosis. This combination is highly suggestive of acute right-sided infective endocarditis (IE).

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of fatigue and low-grade fever. She has no history of serious illness except for a bicuspid aortic valve, diagnosed 10 years ago. She does not use illicit drugs. Her temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F). Physical examination shows petechiae under the fingernails and multiple tender, red nodules on the fingers. A new grade 2/6 diastolic murmur is heard at the right second intercostal space. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

E. faecalis is a common cause of subacute endocarditis that is often associated with nosocomial urinary tract infection or manipulation of the genitourinary tract (e.g., cystoscopy, abortion, delivery). However, this patient has not had a urinary infection or undergone any procedures, making E. faecalis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

S. epidermidis can cause endocarditis, especially in patients with peripheral or central venous catheters and/or surgical implants and devices, where it forms a biofilm over the implanted material. In these cases and in patients who have undergone prosthetic valve surgery (< 60 days post-surgery), S. epidermidis is a common cause of acute endocarditis. This patient, however, has a subacute course of endocarditis with symptoms that have persisted for more than 2 months, and she has had no invasive treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Pharyngitis or tonsillitis caused by S. pyogenes can result in rheumatic fever, which can manifest with fatigue, low-grade fever, a new murmur, and nodules. However, these nodules are typically nontender and located subcutaneously on extensor surfaces. In the case of rheumatic fever, subungual hemorrhage would not be expected, whereas other classic signs of rheumatic fever (e.g., migratory polyarthritis, erythema marginatum) would be present. Moreover, rheumatic fever typically affects children and adolescents, not adults.

Damage to the heart valves caused by rheumatic heart disease is a risk factor for infective endocarditis.

D) CORRECT:

S. sanguinis is a gram-positive member of the viridans streptococci group, which are oral commensal bacteria. Further viridans streptococci include S. mutans and S. mitis. Viridans streptococci are the most common cause of subacute endocarditis in predamaged native valves (such as this patient's bicuspid aortic valve) and endocarditis in prosthetic valves occurring > 60 days post-operation. Viridans streptococci are also a common cause of endocarditis after oral procedures, which frequently lead to transient bacteremia. In patients with predamaged native valves, circulating bacteria may subsequently adhere to and infect platelet-fibrin aggregates that form at sites of endocardial injury, leading to vegetation formation.
Image Description:

Depicted here is the classification of bacteria according to their Gram staining properties. Bacteria are further classified according to morphology, genus, and hemolytic and enzymatic properties.

E) INCORRECT:

S. gallolyticus is an uncommon cause of subacute endocarditis that is usually associated with colon cancer. This patient does not have any features to suggest colon cancer (e.g., weight loss, constipation, GI bleeding).

F) INCORRECT:

S. aureus is the most common cause of acute bacterial endocarditis in all patient groups. It progresses rapidly and often affects previously healthy valves. However, this patient has had a subacute course with symptoms occurring over the past 2 months. S. aureus is therefore unlikely to be the causative organism.

G) INCORRECT:

C. albicans can cause endocarditis in patients who have recently undergone cardiac surgery. Immunocompromised individuals and intravenous drug users are also at risk of C. albicans infection. This patient has none of these risk factors.

H) INCORRECT:

While S. pneumoniae can cause infective endocarditis, affected patients tend to have risk factors such as cirrhosis or HIV infection. This patient has no history of serious illness, making S. pneumoniae an unlikely cause of her endocarditis.
questions.hint: Osler nodes, subungual hemorrhage, and a new murmur in a patient with a 6-week history of fatigue and low-grade fever suggest subacute infective endocarditis. In patients with an underlying valve disease, infection is typically caused by a gram-positive, catalase-negative, coagulase-negative, α-hemolytic, optochin-resistant coccus.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for a 1-month history of fever, malaise, and skin rash. He has had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss during this period. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He appears pale. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows nontender, erythematous macules on the palms and soles. A photograph of one of his fingernails is shown. Microscopic examination of the nail lesion is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

There is growing evidence to suggest that deposition of immune complexes within the capillary beds is a cause of vasculitis leading to splinter hemorrhages, roth spots, and/or glomerulonephritis. However, the offending immune complexes in endocarditis are predominantly formed by IgA and/or IgG, not IgE.

B) INCORRECT:

Aschoff granulomas (Aschoff bodies) form due to inflammation caused by rheumatic fever, which can also manifest with fever, malaise, and skin findings (subcutaneous nodules and erythema marginatum). However, Aschoff bodies would be found in the patient's myocardium rather than his fingernails. Moreover, rheumatic fever mostly occurs within the first two decades of life and would not be expected in this 62-year-old patient. This patient also does not satisfy Jones criteria.

C) INCORRECT:

Arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) occur as congenital connections between arteries and veins. These defects are associated with ischemia and hemorrhages. Unlike this patient's presentation, AVMs do not cause systemic signs such as fever, malaise, and weight loss, and are not associated with forming Janeway lesions.

D) CORRECT:

Microemboli trapped within the capillary networks of nail beds can cause splinter hemorrhages like the ones seen in this patient. These microemboli break off from infected left-heart cardiac valves and enter systemic circulation, where they become trapped in capillary beds throughout the body. In addition, there is growing evidence to suggest that vasculitis due to deposition of immune complexes within the capillary beds contributes to the formation of splinter hemorrhages, roth spots, and glomerulonephritis, all of which can occur in patients with infectious endocarditis. Janeway lesions are caused by microabscesses and neutrophilic capillary infiltration resulting from septic microemboli.
Image Description:

Multiple erythematous macules are visible on the thenar eminence and the base of the thumb.

These Janeway lesions are typically caused by septic microembolisms secondary to infective endocarditis.

E) INCORRECT:

The presence of non-caseating granulomas within the lesion would signify the occurrence of granulomatous inflammation. A granulomatous disease associated with both systemic (fever, malaise, weight loss) and dermatological (splinter hemorrhages, blistering rashes) manifestations similar to those seen in this patient is granulomatosis with polyangiitis. However, this patient does not exhibit the most common features of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (i.e., chronic rhinitis/sinusitis; lower respiratory tract symptoms such as cough, dyspnea, and hemoptysis; and RPGN).
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms of fever, malaise, and weight loss along with his exam findings of Janeway lesions (nontender macules on palms and soles) and splinter hemorrhages (photograph) make infectious endocarditis the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fever, chills, myalgias, and joint pain 1 month after undergoing aortic prosthetic valve replacement due to high-grade aortic stenosis. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.8°F). She appears weak and lethargic. Physical examination shows crackles at both lung bases and a grade 2/6, blowing diastolic murmur over the right sternal border. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. The causal organism is most likely to have which of the following characteristics?

choices.text: Catalase-negative cocci that grows in 6.5% saline

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

S. pneumoniae is an alpha hemolytic, optochin-sensitive diplococcus that may, in extremely rare cases, cause endocarditis. This patient more likely has prosthetic valve endocarditis from S. epidermidis, which is a gamma hemolytic coccus. Furthermore, pneumococcal pneumonia typically causes localized lung consolidation, which manifests in lung crackles in distinct regions, rather than the bibasilar crackles heard in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

S. epidermidis is a novobiocin sensitive, coagulase-negative, catalase-positive, gram-positive coccus with the capability of biofilm formation. As S. epidermidis is part of the normal skin flora, contamination of prosthetic devices (e.g., heart valves and hip implants) may occur during surgery.

Staphylococcus aureus is another common causal pathogen of early prosthetic valve endocarditis (i.e., within 60 days after implantation).

C) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus is a catalase-negative coccus that grows in 6.5% saline. It can cause infective endocarditis, typically following genitourinary or gastrointestinal procedures. However, Enterococcus is only implicated in 8% of cases of endocarditis following valve replacement surgery. S. epidermidis, which is the most likely cause of endocarditis in this patient, is catalase-positive and does not grow in hypertonic saline.

D) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pyogenes is a beta hemolytic, bacitracin sensitive bacterium that can cause acute rheumatic fever (ARF). ARF can manifest with fevers, myalgias, arthralgia, diastolic murmurs at the right sternal border due to aortic regurgitation, basilar lung crackles due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema, increased ESR, and leukocytosis. However, ARF is more common in children and adolescents. It rarely occurs in patients over the age of 45 years.

E) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus bovis and Streptococcus mitis are viridans streptococci (alpha hemolytic, optochin-resistant cocci) that may cause infective endocarditis (IE). However, IE due to viridans streptococci usually occurs following dental or gastrointestinal procedures. The most likely cause of IE in patients with recent heart valve transplants is, however, S. epidermidis (a γ-hemolytic coccus).
questions.hint: In combination with a recent history of aortic valve replacement, this patient's symptoms suggest prosthetic valve endocarditis, the most common cause of which would be Staphylococcus epidermidis infection.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man dies 4 months after being diagnosed with advanced adenocarcinoma of the pancreas. Examination of the heart at autopsy shows vegetations lining the mitral valve margins. The vegetations are loosely attached and can be easily scraped off. Microscopic examination shows the vegetations to be composed of interwoven fibrin strands with mononuclear cells. The mitral valve endothelium is intact. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these autopsy findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Some adenocarcinomas (e.g., pancreas, colon) excrete procoagulant factors (e.g., tissue factor, cancer procoagulant), resulting in sterile vegetations (nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis) composed predominantly of platelets. These white thrombi are easily dislodged from heart valves, placing patients at high risk of developing tissue infarctions (e.g., strokes, myocardial infarctions).

Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis is associated with malignancy and certain autoimmune conditions (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, SLE), and most commonly affects the aortic and mitral valves. Patients are usually asymptomatic until there is evidence of thromboembolic phenomena.

B) INCORRECT:

Dystrophic calcifications occur in previously damaged tissues with chronic inflammation. The patient's advanced age would predispose him to such dystrophic calcification as a result of age-related degeneration of the valves. However, there was no damage found on the patient's endothelium and the vegetations were easily scraped off rather than being firmly attached and showed no hard calcium deposits.

C) INCORRECT:

Antibody cross-reactivity to highly antigenic M protein (virulence factor) of Streptococcus pyogenes occurs in rheumatic fever. A late sequela of this disease is rheumatic heart disease, in which vegetations can form on heart valve surfaces, particularly on the mitral valve. However, such vegetations are inflammatory in nature and do not scrape off easily. Moreover, the endocardium would show signs of damage with probable histological findings of Aschoff bodies.

D) INCORRECT:

Bacterial colonization of the heart valves is seen in infective endocarditis and results in the formation of vegetations of varying size. However, the septic vegetations in infective endocarditis are classically firmly attached to the valvular endothelium and microscopic examination would show dense clusters of bacteria and, possibly, calcification. Moreover, this patient does not show marked inflammation and destruction of the valvular endothelium, as would be expected in acute bacterial endocarditis.

E) INCORRECT:

Metastatic infiltration of heart valves is an infrequent manifestation of cancers, most commonly occurring in melanoma, leukemia, carcinoma of the lung or breast, and rarely in colon cancer. Metastatic heart masses would be infiltrative and destructive, and unlikely to be scraped off easily.
questions.hint: Valvular vegetations interwoven with fibrin strands and mononuclear cells are commonly seen in patients with mucin-producing tumors (e.g., adenocarcinoma of the pancreas or colon) or SLE.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of fever, chills, night sweats, and generalized fatigue for 2 weeks. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F). He appears ill. Physical examination shows a grade 3/6 mid-diastolic murmur at the left sternal border, and crackles at both lung bases. A transesophageal echocardiography shows a 12 mm vegetation on the aortic valve. Blood cultures show gram-positive, catalase-negative, gamma-hemolytic cocci in chains that are unable to grow in a 6.5% NaCl medium. Which of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Periodontal disease is a risk factor for IE caused by viridans group streptococci (e.g., S. mutans). However, Streptococci of the viridans group are alpha-hemolytic organisms, unlike the gamma-hemolytic type seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

S. gallolyticus can be found in the normal bowel flora of healthy humans. There is a well-established link between S. gallolyticus bacteremia (particularly in endocarditis) and colorectal cancer. However, it remains unclear whether S. gallolyticus is part of the etiology of colorectal malignancies or a consequence of the disease. Animal studies suggest that this pathogen may play a role in the pathogenesis of colorectal malignancies. A colonoscopy is indicated in all patients with S. gallolyticus on blood culture.

C) INCORRECT:

Congenital heart defects (CHDs) are associated with an increased risk of IE. The risks vary based on the underlying defect (e.g., VSD, tetralogy of Fallot, and PDA pose high risks; ASD and transposition of the great vessels pose low risks) and the most common etiologic agents are viridans group streptococci and Staphylococcus spp. This patient has no evidence of CHD on his echocardiogram, and S. gallolyticus is not a typical organism of CHD-associated IE.

D) INCORRECT:

A history of valve replacement is a risk factor for IE. IE associated with artificial heart valves is typically due to S. epidermidis, S. aureus, or gram-negative rods if symptoms occur within 60 days after surgery, or due to S. aureus or enterococci if symptoms occur > 60 days after valve replacement. S. gallolyticus, however, is not a typical organism of prosthetic valve endocarditis.

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous drug use is a major risk factor for infective endocarditis (IE). However, whereas this patient shows left-sided vegetations seen, IE associated with IV drug use usually affects the right-sided (tricuspid and pulmonary) valves. Also, the common responsible bacteria for right-sided IE are Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas spp., rather than the S. gallolyticus seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Urinary tract infections can cause bacteremia and subsequent IE in urosepsis, which would manifest with fever, chills, night sweats, and generalized fatigue as well as a heart murmur and valve vegetations. IE in the setting of urosepsis would typically be associated with gram-negative organisms such as E. coli, Klebsiella, and Enterobacter, but not S. gallolyticus.
questions.hint: The patient's blood cultures and echocardiography findings are consistent with aortic regurgitation (diastolic murmur at the left sternal border) due to Streptococcus gallolyticus endocarditis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of fever and poor appetite. Five weeks ago, he underwent molar extraction for dental caries. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Cardiac examination shows a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur heard best at the apex. A blood culture shows gram-positive, catalase-negative cocci. Transesophageal echocardiography shows a small vegetation on the mitral valve with mild regurgitation. The causal organism most likely has which of the following characteristics?

choices.text: Formation of germ tubes at body temperature

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Production of CAMP factor is a unique property of S. agalactiae, a gram-positive, catalase-negative coccus. While S. agalactiae can also cause subacute bacterial endocarditis, it is a very rare causative agent and is usually associated with diabetes mellitus, malignancy, or immunosuppression, not with recent dental surgery.

B) INCORRECT:

Replication in host macrophages is a strategy adopted by many pathogens, including Coxiella burnetii, which can also cause endocarditis (e.g., due to untreated Q fever). However, C. burnetii is a gram-negative bacterium that is very difficult to culture, in contrast to this patient's gram-positive bacterial culture result. Viridans group streptococci do not replicate in host macrophages.

C) INCORRECT:

Formation of germ tubes at body temperature is a characteristic feature of Candida spp., which can cause endocarditis. Fungal endocarditis typically manifests with small vegetations. Risk factors for fungal endocarditis include recent surgery, IV drug use, and immunosuppression, none of which are present in this patient. Furthermore, blood culture would reveal budding yeast, not gram-positive, catalase-negative cocci.

D) CORRECT:

Dental surgery is an important risk factor for subacute endocarditis with viridans group streptococci, which are present in normal oral flora. Viridans group streptococci (especially S. mutans and S. sanguis) produce dextrans, which facilitates binding to tooth enamel, as well as to fibrin-platelet deposits on damaged heart valves. The subsequent formation of a fibrin clot and ensuing inflammation results in the vegetation formation that is characteristic of endocarditis.

E) INCORRECT:

Coagulase, which converts fibrinogen to fibrin, is an enzyme produced by Staphylococcus aureus. S. aureus is also a gram-positive coccus and one of the most common causes of bacterial endocarditis. However, S. aureus is also catalase-positive, whereas the organism seen here is catalase-negative. Furthermore, S. aureus is typically associated with more rapid symptom onset and the formation of relatively large vegetations.
questions.hint: Together with echocardiography showing a small vegetation, protracted fever and loss of appetite after a dental extraction suggest subacute bacterial endocarditis, which is most commonly due to viridans group streptococci.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man comes to the physician for 2 months of intermittent low-grade fever, malaise, and joint pain. He has a history of recurrent dental abscesses requiring drainage but has otherwise been healthy. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F) and pulse is 112/min. Physical examination shows a new holosystolic murmur in the left midclavicular line that radiates to the axilla. There are linear reddish-brown lesions underneath the nail beds and tender violaceous nodules on the bilateral thenar eminences. Two sets of blood cultures grow Streptococcus mutans. A transthoracic echocardiogram shows moderate regurgitation of the mitral valve. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely directly involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's valvular condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve is the underlying pathology of mitral valve prolapse (MVP). MVP is a risk factor for infective endocarditis, which this patient has, but it is not directly involved in the pathogenesis of the disease. It is most often an incidental finding on auscultation in asymptomatic patients. This patient presents with a new murmur on auscultation, making a pre-existing MVP unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Antibody cross-reaction due to molecular mimicry is the presumed pathogenic mechanism of rheumatic fever (RF). Acute RF may manifest with mitral regurgitation, joint pain, skin manifestations, and fever, all of which this patient has. However, RF also manifests with typical skin findings, such as erythema marginatum and subcutaneous nodules, which are not seen here. Moreover, this patient has no history of sore throat or group A streptococcal infection, which typically precede RF. Furthermore, blood cultures are negative in RF as it is an immunologic, non-infectious condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) results from sterile (i.e., noninfectious) platelet thrombi deposition on the cardiac valves. NBTE most commonly affects the mitral valve; however, it typically manifests with signs and symptoms of systemic embolization rather than mitral valve dysfunction, which is seen here. This patient presents with fever and bacteremia, which is highly suggestive of infectious endocarditis. Moreover, NBTE usually affects patients with advanced malignancy or systemic lupus erythematosus, neither of which this patient has.

D) INCORRECT:

Leaflet calcification and fibrosis are pathologic changes seen in mitral stenosis (MS) due to rheumatic fever (RF). While MS does produce a murmur in the left midclavicular line, it is a diastolic murmur that follows an opening snap. Moreover, this patient has a TTE with evidence of mitral regurgitation, not stenosis. While acute RF can also manifest with joint pain, fever, and malaise, MS would not be expected until 10 to 20 years after the original illness, and blood cultures would be negative. Finally, this patient presents with subacute infective endocarditis, which individuals with MS are at an increased risk of developing, but calcification and fibrosis play no direct part in the pathogenesis of this condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Coagulative necrosis is the mechanism that causes cell death in myocardial infarction (MI). Acute mitral regurgitation, as seen in this patient, can be a complication of MI. However, further symptoms such as left-sided chest pain, dyspnea, nausea, and diaphoresis would be expected. This patient presents instead with fever, bacteremia, and skin findings that are highly suggestive of infectious endocarditis.

F) CORRECT:

Fibrin clot formation is a key step in the pathogenesis of subacute infective endocarditis. First, endothelial damage occurs (in native valves this is typically due to turbulent blood flow), followed by adherence of platelets and fibrin to the damaged valve areas. These initially sterile platelet-fibrin aggregates can become infected by bacteria circulating in the blood, forming vegetations. This patient is at increased risk for streptococcal bacteremia due to recurrent dental abscesses. Microbial adherence to the platelet-fibrin nidus is mediated by interaction of bacterial cell wall components (e.g., dextrans) and the valvular endothelium. Fibrin clots encase this vegetation and subsequent destruction of the affected valves leads to valvular insufficiency, as seen here. This patient's physical examination findings of splinter hemorrhages and Osler nodes represent areas of microembolization of vegetation material.

Infective endocarditis should always be considered in a patient with a fever of unknown origin.
Image Description:

Photograph of a dissected heart specimen opened to show the endocardial aspect of left atrium and ventricle

The mitral valve is thickened (indicated by arrow) and shows numerous yellow vegetations on the atrial (superior) aspect of the valve (examples indicated by arrowheads).

This gross appearance is typical of infective endocarditis of the mitral valve.
questions.hint: The patient meets two of the major (modified) Duke Criteria for infective endocarditis: two blood cultures growing a typical pathogen and evidence of a new valvular regurgitation on transthoracic echocardiogram. The 2-month history of intermittent illness, recurrent dental abscesses, and isolation of S. mutans on blood cultures make subacute infective endocarditis the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman is being prepared to undergo orthodontic bracket placement for a dental overbite. She feels well. Three years ago, she underwent splenectomy for traumatic splenic rupture. She does not have any known allergies and has no family history of serious illness. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her only medication is a multivitamin. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 124/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Cardiac auscultation shows a normal S1 and S2 and no murmurs. The patient is concerned about her asplenic state and asks the physician if she needs to take any antibiotics to decrease her risk of infection. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation by the physician?

choices.text: Administration of oral amoxicillin 60 minutes prior to the procedure
Following the procedure, daily administration of oral penicillin V for one year
Administration of intravenous cefazolin 30 minutes prior to the procedure
Administration of oral azithromycin 30 minutes prior to the procedure
Following the procedure, monthly administration of intramuscular penicillin G for 5 years

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Administration of oral amoxicillin 60 minutes prior to the procedure is the first-line therapy for infective endocarditis prophylaxis, which is indicated in high-risk patients undergoing procedures with a significant risk of bacteremia. Orthodontic bracket placement is not considered a dental procedure with a high risk of bacteremia.

B) INCORRECT:

Daily administration of oral penicillin V for one year is indicated after splenectomy in children under 5 years of age to prevent infections with encapsulated bacteria. However, daily antibiotic therapy for one year is not recommended in adult patients after splenectomy, and it is not indicated after dental procedures in asplenic patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Administration of intravenous cefazolin 30 minutes prior to the procedure is indicated for endocarditis prophylaxis in patients who are unable to take oral penicillin (first-line). Endocarditis prophylaxis is indicated in high-risk patients undergoing procedures with a significant risk of bacteremia. Orthodontic bracket placement is not considered a dental procedure with a high risk of bacteremia. Furthermore, this patient does not have nausea or vomiting and has no history of a condition that impairs deglutition.

D) INCORRECT:

Administration of oral azithromycin 30 minutes prior to the procedure is indicated for endocarditis prophylaxis in patients who are allergic to penicillin. Endocarditis prophylaxis is indicated in high-risk patients undergoing procedures with a significant risk of bacteremia. Orthodontic bracket placement is not considered a dental procedure with a high risk of bacteremia. Furthermore, this patient does not have a history of allergy to penicillin.

E) CORRECT:

Antibiotic prophylaxis should be considered in patients with asplenia who are undergoing procedures that increase the risk of infection with encapsulated bacteria (i.e., procedures involving the paranasal sinuses and respiratory tract). In addition, asplenic patients may receive antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis (IE) if they undergo procedures with a high risk of bacteremia, e.g., tooth extraction. These procedures, however, do not include orthodontic bracket placement. This patient will undergo a dental procedure with a low risk of infection with encapsulated bacteria or bacteremia and she has no other indications for endocarditis prophylaxis (e.g., history of IE); therefore, no antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated.

IE prophylaxis is recommended for dental procedures that involve manipulation of the gingiva (e.g., tooth extraction, professional dental cleaning) in patients with the following heart defects: history of IE; prosthetic material used for cardiac valve repair/replacement; unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease (CHD); repaired CHD with residual defects; repaired CHD during the first 6 months after the procedure; history of cardiac transplant with cardiac valvulopathy.

F) INCORRECT:

Monthly administration of intramuscular penicillin G for 5 years or until the patient reaches 21 years of age is used as secondary prevention of rheumatic heart disease in patients with a history of rheumatic fever without carditis. This patient does not have a history of rheumatic fever.
questions.hint: This would also be the most appropriate recommendation for this patient if she did not have asplenia.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man is evaluated for fever, dyspnea, and myalgia 7 days after admission to the hospital for acute traumatic pancreatitis. Since admission, his general condition improved significantly under adequate treatment. His current symptoms started suddenly and worsened over the course of the past 6 hours. He has hypercholesterolemia and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His current medications are fentanyl, insulin, and atorvastatin. He has received lactated Ringer solution via a central venous catheter. His temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a soft nontender abdomen. Bowel sounds are normal. Cardiac examination discloses a holosystolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is erythema and purulent discharge at the central venous catheter insertion site at the right side of the neck. Hemoglobin concentration is 13.8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 16,000/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 40 mm/h. Results of blood cultures are pending. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

HAECK organisms such as Haemophilus aphrophilus are a rare cause of IE (usually in individuals with poor dental hygiene and periodontal infection). However, H. aphrophilus is not associated with CLABSI. Moreover, HAECK organisms typically cause subacute IE, whereas this patient has acute IE.

B) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa can cause healthcare-associated infections, often in association with known prior colonization, but other pathogens are more commonly associated with CLABSI. In addition, IE due to P. aeruginosa is rare and typically associated with IV drug use.

C) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus gallolyticus can occasionally cause acute IE, typically in association with colorectal cancer. However, S. gallolyticus is not a typical causative agent for CLABSI. Moreover, this patient has no history or clinical features to suggest colorectal carcinoma (e.g., weight loss, GI bleeding, abdominal mass).

D) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is a common cause of healthcare-associated infections, especially catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI), but other pathogens are more commonly associated with CLABSI. In addition, IE due to E. coli is rare and typically associated with risk factors such as immunosuppression, excessive alcohol consumption, indwelling urinary tract catheter, and/or urinary tract infection, none of which is seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Klebsiella pneumoniae can cause healthcare-associated infections, but other pathogens are more commonly associated with CLABSI. In addition, K. pneumoniae usually causes infections in immunosuppressed adults and is a rare causative agent of IE.

F) CORRECT:

Staphylococci such as S. aureus account for the majority of cases of healthcare-associated IE. IE caused by S. aureus is characterized by acute onset of symptoms and rapid progression (hours to days). Acute IE due to S. aureus can quickly lead to complications such as valvular insufficiency, heart failure, and septic emboli. Therefore, in addition to removing the infected CVC, empiric antibiotic therapy (vancomycin plus beta-lactam for native valve endocarditis) should be initiated after obtaining blood cultures.

Coagulase-negative staphylococci (e.g., S. epidermidis), S. aureus, enterococci, and Candida spp. are the organisms most commonly associated with CLABSI. Note that IE associated with coagulase-negative staphylococci typically has a subacute course with an insidious onset (weeks to months), low-grade fever, and nonspecific symptoms, unlike the fulminant course seen in this patient.
questions.hint: The acute onset of fever, dyspnea, and myalgia, in combination with a cardiac murmur, raises concern for acute infective endocarditis (IE). Local signs of infection (erythema, purulent discharge) at the central venous catheter (CVC) insertion site make a central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI) the most likely cause of this patient's current condition.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman is referred by her dentist for evaluation before urgent dental work and cleaning. Her parents told her that she was “born blue” and required two surgeries on her heart, one shortly after birth and another a couple of months later. She currently takes an oral iron supplement and an oral contraceptive pill. She has no known drug allergies.
The patient is afebrile. Her blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg in the right arm and 120/80 mm Hg in the left arm. She has a regular heart rate at 75 beats per minute and an oxygen saturation of 90% while breathing ambient air.
She has a normal first heart sound; a fixed, split second heart sound; a right parasternal heave; and a soft, early diastolic decrescendo murmur, best appreciated over the left lower sternal border. She has no evidence of elevated jugular venous pressure and no lower-extremity edema. Her right radial pulse is diminished compared with her left.
In addition to referring this patient for further cardiac evaluation, which one of the following recommendations for the dental procedure is most appropriate?

choices.text: Prescribe clindamycin 600 mg by mouth the night before the procedure
Prescribe ampicillin 2 g intravenously 4 hours before the procedure
Prescribe cephalexin 2 g by mouth the morning of the procedure
Prescribe amoxicillin 2 g by mouth one hour before the procedure

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient had cyanotic congenital heart disease from birth and does not appear to have had a complete repair. She has residual shunting, as demonstrated by the persistent murmur and low oxygen saturation while she is breathing ambient air. In addition to referral to an adult congenital heart disease expert, she should receive endocarditis prophylaxis before a dental procedure.

B) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin is no longer recommended as prophylaxis for infective endocarditis because it is associated with higher rates of Clostridioides difficile infection and potential complications from such infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Ampicillin, cefazolin, and ceftriaxone are acceptable alternatives if the patient cannot tolerate an antibiotic by mouth.

D) INCORRECT:

Cephalexin, azithromycin, clarithromycin, and doxycycline are acceptable alternatives if the patient can tolerate those agents and is allergic to amoxicillin.

E) CORRECT:

Guidelines previously recommended that all patients with a history of congenital heart disease, regardless of cause or prior intervention, receive endocarditis prophylaxis with antibiotics one hour before a dental procedure or an operation on the mouth or throat, or on the gastrointestinal, genital, or urinary tract. However, the American Heart Association has since revised those recommendations, limiting antibiotic prophylaxis to the following groups of patients, deemed to be at greatest risk for infective endocarditis:

1 Patients who have prosthetic cardiac valves, including transcatheter-implanted prostheses and homografts

2 Patients who have prosthetic material used for cardiac valve repair, such as annuloplasty rings and chords

3 Patients with previous infective endocarditis

4 Patients with unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease or repaired congenital heart disease, with residual shunts or valvular regurgitation at the site of or adjacent to the site of a prosthetic patch or prosthetic device

5 Patients who have a cardiac transplant with valve regurgitation due to a structurally abnormal valve

This patient had cyanotic congenital heart disease from birth and does not appear to have had a complete repair. She has residual shunting, as demonstrated by the persistent murmur and low oxygen saturation while she is breathing ambient air. In addition to referral to an adult congenital heart disease expert, she should receive endocarditis prophylaxis before a dental procedure.

In all patients without known drug allergies who can tolerate oral intake, the most appropriate antibiotic drug for endocarditis prophylaxis before a dental procedure is amoxicillin. Any antibiotic prophylaxis should be taken 30 to 60 minutes before the procedure.

Key learning point: When indicated, the antibiotic of choice for the prevention of endocarditis in a patient having a dental procedure is amoxicillin.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man with end-stage kidney disease is admitted to the intensive care unit with methicillin-resistant, vancomycin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia and mitral valve endocarditis. A transesophageal echocardiogram reveals a 1-cm vegetation on the mitral valve and mild mitral regurgitation.
The patient is treated with intravenous vancomycin, and daily serum trough levels document therapeutic levels of the antibiotic. Repeat blood cultures are positive 7 days after admission and initiation of vancomycin; the S. aureus is still susceptible to vancomycin.
The patient is hemodynamically stable. He has a 2/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex; splinter hemorrhages on his fingernails are unchanged since admission.
No other site of infection is found on evaluation.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The patient is already on appropriate antibiotic therapy, so adding more antibiotics or switching therapy is unlikely to be beneficial.

B) INCORRECT:

The patient is already on appropriate antibiotic therapy, so adding more antibiotics or switching therapy is unlikely to be beneficial.

C) CORRECT:

Despite modern therapy, morbidity and mortality associated with infective endocarditis remains high. The mainstay of treatment for native-valve infective endocarditis is tailored, long-term, parenteral antibiotic therapy. However, surgical intervention is warranted in certain circumstances, including new-onset heart failure, persistently positive blood cultures, perivalvular abscess, and embolic events despite appropriate antibiotic therapy.

This patient has persistently positive blood cultures one week after being hospitalized and receiving appropriate antibiotic therapy. He should be evaluated for surgery to replace the infected valve.

Key learning point: The most appropriate intervention for a patient with infective endocarditis and persistently positive blood cultures despite 7 days of appropriate antibiotic therapy is valve replacement surgery.

D) INCORRECT:

Continuing with current therapy would be inappropriate in a patient whose repeat blood cultures show persistence of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. Patients with persistent high-grade bacteremia should be evaluated for the presence of a metastatic abscess.

E) INCORRECT:

The patient is already on appropriate antibiotic therapy, so adding more antibiotics or switching therapy is unlikely to be beneficial.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man is hospitalized with a 2-week history of high-grade fevers and leukocytosis. On his second hospital day, he reports severe dyspnea.
Physical examination reveals diaphoresis and moderate respiratory distress. The patient has a temperature of 39.0°C, a regular heart rate of 110 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 104/61 mm Hg, and a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 86% while he is breathing ambient air.
A cardiac examination reveals tachycardia, a short soft early diastolic murmur at the cardiac base and mid-sternum, and a third heart sound. Inspiratory crackles are detected halfway up both lung fields. The patient has no lower-extremity edema, but his hands and feet are cool to the touch.
The patient's admission electrocardiogram reveals sinus tachycardia and a PR interval of 0.26 seconds.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient's acute decompensation?

choices.text: Pneumonia with acute respiratory distress syndrome

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute mitral insufficiency would cause a systolic murmur at the cardiac apex.

B) INCORRECT:

Acute pulmonary valve insufficiency would not present with features of left-sided heart failure.

C) CORRECT:

The combination of fevers, leukocytosis, and a diastolic murmur should raise suspicion for aortic valve endocarditis. Prolongation of the PR interval on the electrocardiogram suggests that the infection has extended into the valve annulus, with formation of a perivalvular abscess. With acute, severe aortic valve regurgitation, left ventricular filling pressure increases and cardiac output falls, resulting in pulmonary edema and systemic hypoperfusion, respectively. Unlike chronic aortic regurgitation, a widened pulse pressure is not detected in patients with acute aortic insufficiency. In acute severe aortic regurgitation, the diastolic murmur is often soft and limited to early diastole, because the rapid increase in left ventricular filling pressure results in equalization of the aortic and left ventricular pressures early in diastole.

Key learning point: A prolonged PR interval in a young adult, combined with fevers and pulmonary edema, can be indicative of aortic valve endocarditis with acute aortic insufficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Septic emboli can explain the fevers and leukocytosis but would not be expected to cause a prolonged PR interval on the electrocardiogram or a diastolic murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

Pneumonia with acute respiratory distress syndrome can explain the fevers and leukocytosis but would not be expected to cause a prolonged PR interval on the electrocardiogram or a diastolic murmur.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath. He has a history of intravenous drug use but has otherwise been healthy.
His temperature is 38.6°C, his heart rate is 120 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg, his respiratory rate is 30 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 85% while he is breathing ambient air.
Cardiac examination reveals tachycardia and a short, soft, decrescendo diastolic murmur at the lower left sternal border. Jugular venous pressure is markedly elevated to the angle of the mandible when the patient is at a 45° incline.
Laboratory evaluation reveals a leukocyte count of 22,000 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000) but an otherwise normal complete blood count and normal electrolyte levels.
A chest radiograph shows bilateral pulmonary edema and a normal cardiac silhouette.
An echocardiogram reveals a 2-cm vegetation on the aortic valve, severe aortic regurgitation, and preserved left ventricular systolic function.
His symptoms and signs persist despite institution of empiric antibiotics and measures to treat heart failure.
In addition to starting intravenous antibiotics and furosemide, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Afterload reduction with an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor
Completion of a 4- to 6-week course of intravenous antibiotics followed by surgical consultation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous anticoagulation (e.g., with heparin) has not been shown to reduce embolic risk or vegetative size in patients with infective endocarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors are sometimes given to reduce afterload in patients with stable chronic aortic regurgitation, but they have no role in patients with acute severe aortic regurgitation and pulmonary edema.

C) INCORRECT:

Treatment with intravenous antibiotics without valve surgery is more appropriate for a patient who has infective endocarditis without heart failure.

D) CORRECT:

In a patient with native-valve endocarditis, indications for surgery include:

• Valve stenosis or regurgitation resulting in heart failure
• Infection with a fungus or another highly resistant organism
• Complications of heart block, an annular or aortic abscess, or a destructive penetrating lesion
• Persistent bacteremia or fever, despite appropriate antibiotics, that is not due to another source
• Recurrent emboli and persistent or enlarging valvular vegetations (despite appropriate antibiotics)

Given this patient’s acute heart failure, urgent aortic valve replacement is the most appropriate first-line therapy.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management for a patient with infective endocarditis and acute heart failure is urgent cardiac surgery.

E) INCORRECT:

Severe aortic regurgitation is a contraindication for placement of an intraaortic balloon and is therefore not indicated in this patient.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man reports a 2-day history of orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He was well until about a month ago, when he began to notice dyspnea on exertion and malaise during daily activities. He reports subjective fevers at home during the past 2 weeks. His medical history includes coronary artery disease, lower gastrointestinal bleeding from diverticulosis, and aortic stenosis, for which he received a bioprosthetic valve 9 years ago.
His current temperature is 38.3°C. He has bilateral rales on pulmonary examination and a new, soft, early diastolic decrescendo murmur at the left upper sternal border on cardiac examination.
A chest radiograph shows pulmonary edema. A transesophageal echocardiogram shows decreased left and right ventricular systolic function, with a well-seated aortic valve prosthesis and no signs of aortic-root abscess or paravalvular insufficiency. A mobile echodensity is evident on the bioprosthetic aortic valve, with 3+ aortic insufficiency that is due to incomplete coaptation of the prosthetic leaflets.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient?

choices.text: Treat with intravenous vancomycin; evaluate for repeat aortic valve replacement
Treat with intravenous vancomycin, gentamicin, and cefepime; observe
Treat with intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin; observe
Treat with intravenous cefepime and gentamicin; observe
Treat with intravenous vancomycin, gentamicin, and cefepime; evaluate for repeat aortic valve replacement

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Initiation of a single intravenous antibiotic is not appropriate, as empiric two- or three-drug regimens are the treatments of choice for PVE. After culture results are available, the antibiotic regimen can be selected to reflect drug sensitivities. Transcatheter aortic valve replacement is not appropriate for PVE.

B) INCORRECT:

The indications for surgery in a patient with PVE include the presence of valvular dysfunction (severe regurgitation) leading to heart failure or shock, fistula/pseudoaneurysm or perivalvular abscess, systemic embolization (from vegetation), fungal or drug-resistant organisms (as well as staphylococcal species), and the presence of persistent bacteremia or recurrent emboli despite appropriate antibiotics. Patients with infective endocarditis complicated by heart failure have a better outcome with early valve replacement than with observation. Hence, antibiotic therapy with only observation is not an appropriate treatment strategy.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with infective endocarditis complicated by heart failure have a better outcome with early valve replacement than with observation. Hence, antibiotic therapy with only observation is not an appropriate treatment strategy.

D) INCORRECT:

Initiation of a single intravenous antibiotic is not appropriate, as empiric two- or three-drug regimens are the treatments of choice for PVE. After culture results are available, the antibiotic regimen can be selected to reflect drug sensitivities. Patients with infective endocarditis complicated by heart failure have a better outcome with early valve replacement than with observation. Hence, antibiotic therapy with only observation is not an appropriate treatment strategy.

E) CORRECT:

Prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE) accounts for 10% to 20% of cases of infective endocarditis. Eventually, 5% of mechanical and bioprosthetic valves become infected. Endocarditis can lead to valve incompetence, with subsequent heart failure, systemic emboli, perivalvular abscess, hemolysis, and conduction disturbances (e.g., atrioventricular block).

Empiric two- or three-drug regimens are the treatments of choice for PVE. After culture results are available, the antibiotic regimen can be selected to reflect drug sensitivities.

The indications for surgery in a patient with PVE include the presence of valvular dysfunction (severe regurgitation) leading to heart failure or shock, fistula/pseudoaneurysm or perivalvular abscess, systemic embolization (from vegetation), fungal or drug-resistant organisms (as well as staphylococcal species), and the presence of persistent bacteremia or recurrent emboli despite appropriate antibiotics.

Key learning point: The primary treatment for prosthetic valve endocarditis complicated by heart failure is early initiation of an appropriate intravenous drug regimen as well as referral for prompt replacement of the diseased valve.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman is hospitalized after reporting a one-week history of fever and dyspnea, as well as orthopnea the night before her hospitalization. She has no significant medical history.
On presentation, her heart rate is 102 beats per minute, her blood pressure is 108/55 mm Hg, and her oxygen saturation is 86% while she is breathing ambient air. She has a high-pitched diastolic murmur at the left sternal border, an S3 gallop, inspiratory crackles, and a nontender macular rash on her soles.
Laboratory evaluation reveals leukocytosis. An electrocardiogram identifies sinus tachycardia, and a chest radiograph shows cephalization of the pulmonary vessels. An echocardiogram documents a normal left ventricular ejection fraction, as well as a vegetation on the aortic valve with severe aortic regurgitation.
Blood cultures from hospital day 1 are positive for Streptococcus sanguinis.
The patient's symptoms and signs persist despite institution of empiric antibiotics and measures to treat heart failure.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Insertion of an intraaortic balloon pump
Six weeks of intravenous antibiotic treatment and a repeat echocardiogram

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A ventricular assist device is used for advanced heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. It is not indicated in a patient with a normal left ventricular ejection fraction who has heart failure that is due to severe valvular disease.

B) CORRECT:

Heart failure resulting from valve dysfunction in a patient with endocarditis is an indication for early valve replacement. Other indications for surgery include infection with fungus or organisms highly resistant to antibiotic therapy, complete heart block, perivalvular abscess formation, fistula formation, and persistently positive blood cultures despite >5 days of appropriate antibiotic therapy.

Key learning point: A patient with native-valve endocarditis who has aortic valve regurgitation leading to heart failure should undergo surgical replacement of the valve.

C) INCORRECT:

An intraaortic balloon pump is contraindicated in patients with advanced aortic-valve insufficiency and would be expected to worsen the patient’s heart failure.

D) INCORRECT:

The patient’s aortic regurgitation is a result of structural damage to the aortic valve caused by the infection; therefore, surgical removal of the vegetation (without replacing the valve) is not sufficient.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient requires surgical management, so intravenous antibiotic therapy for 6 weeks followed by a repeat echocardiogram is inadequate.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man with a history of heart disease has been told that, according to current guidelines, he should take oral amoxicillin 30 minutes before dental procedures that are expected to require manipulation of the gingival tissue.
Which one of the following cardiac conditions is consistent with this advice for this patient?

choices.text: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with a gradient at rest
Mitral valve prolapse with mitral regurgitation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conditions that do not necessitate prophylaxis include valve repair without prosthetic material, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with or without obstruction, mitral valve prolapse with or without regurgitation, bicuspid aortic valve, and aortic stenosis. Prophylaxis is not recommended for nondental procedures, such as transesophageal echocardiography and gastrointestinal or genitourinary procedures, except in the setting of active infection at the site of the procedure.

B) INCORRECT:

Conditions that do not necessitate prophylaxis include valve repair without prosthetic material, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with or without obstruction, mitral valve prolapse with or without regurgitation, bicuspid aortic valve, and aortic stenosis. Prophylaxis is not recommended for nondental procedures, such as transesophageal echocardiography and gastrointestinal or genitourinary procedures, except in the setting of active infection at the site of the procedure.

C) INCORRECT:

Conditions that do not necessitate prophylaxis include valve repair without prosthetic material, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with or without obstruction, mitral valve prolapse with or without regurgitation, bicuspid aortic valve, and aortic stenosis. Prophylaxis is not recommended for nondental procedures, such as transesophageal echocardiography and gastrointestinal or genitourinary procedures, except in the setting of active infection at the site of the procedure.

D) INCORRECT:

Conditions that do not necessitate prophylaxis include valve repair without prosthetic material, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with or without obstruction, mitral valve prolapse with or without regurgitation, bicuspid aortic valve, and aortic stenosis. Prophylaxis is not recommended for nondental procedures, such as transesophageal echocardiography and gastrointestinal or genitourinary procedures, except in the setting of active infection at the site of the procedure.

E) CORRECT:

Antimicrobial prophylaxis for bacterial endocarditis is appropriate before a dental procedure involving manipulation of the gingival tissue, affecting the periapical region of the teeth, or requiring perforation of the oral mucosa in patients with one or more of the following cardiac conditions:

• Prosthetic (bioprosthetic or mechanical) cardiac valves, including transcatheter-implanted prostheses and homografts
• Prosthetic material used for cardiac valve repair, such as annuloplasty rings and chords
• Previous infective endocarditis
• Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease or repaired congenital heart disease, with residual shunts or valvular regurgitation at the site of or adjacent to the site of a prosthetic patch or prosthetic device
• Cardiac transplant with valve regurgitation due to a structurally abnormal valve

The first-line prophylactic antibiotic regimen for dental procedures is a single dose of amoxicillin. The alternatives for penicillin-allergic individuals are cephalexin, doxycycline, azithromycin, and clarithromycin.

Key learning point: The cardiac conditions that are an indication for antibiotic prophylaxis for bacterial endocarditis before dental procedures include prosthetic heart valves (bioprosthetic or mechanical), previous valve repair with prosthetic material, heart transplant with valvulopathy, prior infective endocarditis, and certain types of congenital heart disease.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man is hospitalized with a 3-day history of high fever, myalgias, shaking chills, and progressive dyspnea. He also reports a 3- to 4-week history of general malaise. He has a history of type 2 diabetes, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and recurrent urinary tract infections. He has no known drug allergies.
On admission, his temperature is 39.4° C, his blood pressure is 108/76 mm Hg, his heart rate is 118 beats per minute, his respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 92% while he is breathing ambient air. On examination, he has a diastolic murmur that is graded 2 on a scale of 1 to 4 and bibasilar crackles. The rest of his examination is unremarkable. He is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
Blood cultures are drawn, and he is started on empiric antibiotic treatment with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam. His pertinent laboratory results show a leukocyte count of 18,000 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000) and a creatinine level of 0.8 mg/dL (0.8–1.3) (estimated creatinine clearance > 60 mL/min). A transthoracic echocardiogram shows a small mobile echodensity on the aortic valve that is confirmed as an 8-mm vegetation. There is also mild-to-moderate aortic insufficiency.
On hospital day 2, blood cultures grow gram-positive cocci in pairs and chains that are later identified as Enterococcus faecalis, susceptible to ampicillin, penicillin, and vancomycin; there is no high-grade aminoglycoside resistance reported.
Which one of the following antibiotic treatment regimens is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In ampicillin-susceptible Enterococcus faecalis endocarditis, ampicillin is preferred over vancomycin.

B) INCORRECT:

In ampicillin-susceptible Enterococcus faecalis endocarditis, ampicillin is preferred over vancomycin. There is no added benefit or synergy with combined ampicillin and vancomycin.

C) INCORRECT:

For many years, the standard treatment for enterococcal endocarditis was a cell wall-active antibiotic, such as ampicillin, plus an aminoglycoside, usually gentamicin. However, this combination carries a higher risk of nephrotoxicity than the double beta-lactam regimen of ampicillin plus ceftriaxone. Thus, most experts currently favor the double beta-lactam regimen, which has comparable efficacy. In this patient with normal renal function, ampicillin plus gentamicin could be considered, but vancomycin plus gentamicin is not a regimen that is used.

D) INCORRECT:

Ampicillin-sulbactam does not offer any additional benefit over ampicillin alone and would expose the patient to unnecessary gram-negative coverage.

E) CORRECT:

Compared with streptococci, enterococci are relatively tolerant to penicillin, ampicillin, and vancomycin. These antibiotics inhibit the growth of enterococci but do not kill them. Therefore, in the case of serious infections such as endocarditis, patients should receive a two-drug regimen.

For many years, the standard treatment for enterococcal endocarditis was a cell wall-active antibiotic, such as ampicillin, plus an aminoglycoside, usually gentamicin. However, this combination carries a higher risk of nephrotoxicity than the double beta-lactam regimen of ampicillin plus ceftriaxone. Thus, most experts currently favor the double beta-lactam regimen, which has comparable efficacy.

Key learning point: The most appropriate antibiotic treatment for a patient with ampicillin-susceptible Enterococcus endocarditis includes a two-drug regimen with ampicillin and ceftriaxone.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents with fever and dyspnea that has progressed during the past week. He has a history of injection-drug use.
On examination, his temperature is 39.1°C. He has a diastolic murmur and crackles in both lung fields. He has track marks in his antecubital fossae and groin.
A chest radiograph reveals pulmonary edema.
A transthoracic echocardiogram reveals aortic insufficiency and a 1.5-cm mobile vegetation on the aortic valve. Blood cultures from admission become positive within 48 hours; Gram stain demonstrates large gram-positive organisms with pseudohyphae.
In addition to surgical intervention, which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin has no activity against Candida.

B) INCORRECT:

Gentamicin has no activity against Candida.

C) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone has no activity against Candida.

D) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole is often used for suppressive therapy after combined medical and surgical intervention; it is only appropriate after a fluconazole-resistant species of Candida is ruled out.

E) CORRECT:

Injection-drug use is a risk factor for the development of native-valve infectious endocarditis. Most cases of infectious endocarditis that occur in people who inject drugs are caused by Staphylococcus aureus, but these people are also at risk for infection with unusual pathogens, including gram-negative bacilli and fungi, particularly Candida. Candida albicans grows on routine blood cultures, appearing as large gram-positive organisms with pseudohyphae. S. aureus are also gram-positive cocci but are smaller and do not produce pseudohyphae. The tricuspid valve is often affected in people who inject drugs, but infection can affect any valve. Blood cultures positive for yeast within 48 hours in the setting of an aortic vegetation suggests infectious endocarditis due to Candida spp.

Given the high mortality rates associated with fungal endocarditis, amphotericin, which is a fungicidal agent, is the preferred initial antimicrobial agent. Addition of flucytosine may be beneficial. Fungal endocarditis is also an indication for surgical intervention.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment regimen for a patient with infective endocarditis due to Candida spp. consists of amphotericin in addition to surgical management.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents to discuss her dentist's recommendation that she take antibiotics before routine dental cleanings. About 10 years ago, she had an echocardiogram that showed mitral valve prolapse. Currently, she has no physical complaints; she exercises regularly and has no exertional dyspnea or chest pain. Her physical examination reveals a midsystolic click at the lower left sternal border and apex; the examination is otherwise normal.
How should you counsel this patient with regard to preventing infective endocarditis?

choices.text: Repeat the echocardiogram and then make the decision about antibiotic prophylaxis
Explain that antibiotics are not warranted

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin lacks reliable activity against oral streptococci and is therefore not an appropriate choice for prophylaxis before dental procedures, even for patients who meet criteria for prophylaxis.

B) INCORRECT:

Repeating an echocardiogram is unnecessary in this case; the patient is asymptomatic, her examination is consistent with the previous diagnosis of mitral valve prolapse, and there is no plausible echocardiographic finding that would change the decision to avoid antibiotic prophylaxis.

C) INCORRECT:

In patients who do require antibiotic prophylaxis, oral amoxicillin is the preferred treatment. Cephalexin, azithromycin, clarithromycin, or doxycycline may be used if the patient has a penicillin allergy. Caution should be exercised with the use of macrolide antibiotics in patients who are predisposed to develop a prolonged corrected QT (QTc) interval, such as those who have baseline QTc prolongation and those who are taking medications that either also prolong the QTc interval or inhibit cytochrome P-450 3A4 enzymes (e.g., antifungal medications, diltiazem, verapamil, and amiodarone).

D) CORRECT:

According to 2020 guidelines from the American Heart Association, patients undergoing dental procedures that involve manipulation of gingival tissue, manipulation of the periapical region of teeth, or perforation of the oral mucosa should receive antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis if they have any of the following cardiac conditions:

• Prosthetic cardiac valves, including transcatheter-implanted prostheses and homografts
• Prosthetic material used for cardiac valve repair, such as annuloplasty rings and chords
• Previous infective endocarditis
• Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease or repaired congenital heart disease, with residual shunts or valvular regurgitation at the site of or adjacent to the site of a prosthetic patch or prosthetic device
• Cardiac transplant with valve regurgitation due to a structurally abnormal valve

This patient does not have any of the conditions listed above and therefore does not require antibiotic prophylaxis in this setting. The estimated absolute risk for infective endocarditis from a dental procedure in patients with mitral valve prolapse is 1 per 1.1 million procedures.

Key learning point: Patients with asymptomatic mitral valve prolapses do not need to receive antibiotic prophylaxis before a dental cleaning.

E) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin is no longer recommended for prophylaxis due to higher rates of Clostridioides difficile infection.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man with hypertension presents to the hospital with a 2-day history of fever (up to 39.6°C), malaise, and myalgias at home. Three sets of peripheral blood cultures, obtained 15 minutes apart, grow methicillin-resistant, vancomycin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus. The microbiology laboratory reports that the organism is sensitive to vancomycin.
On physical examination, the patient has tachycardia (heart rate, 110 beats per minute) but no murmurs or gallops on auscultation. His skin, musculoskeletal, and neurologic examinations are normal. A transthoracic echocardiogram documents a left ventricular ejection fraction of 55% without evidence of vegetations.
Despite 7 days of treatment with intravenous vancomycin, the patient remains febrile, and follow-up blood cultures are negative. Laboratory testing reveals that his most recent vancomycin trough is appropriate. He does not have any localizing symptoms or findings on examination.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for managing this patient?

choices.text: Order blood cultures using the lysis-centrifugation technique
Obtain CT of the abdomen and pelvis
Obtain a tagged white-blood-cell nuclear scan

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia can lead to native-valve infective endocarditis (IE); this can occur with both methicillin-sensitive and methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA). Given the potential for invasive disease due to this organism, IE should be diagnosed quickly with a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE). A negative transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) does not rule out IE, as a TTE’s sensitivity for IE is much lower than that of a TEE. In particular, a TEE may find evidence of intramyocardial or ring abscesses that could warrant surgery.

If the TEE is negative in a patient with MRSA bacteremia and ongoing fever, additional aggressive investigation is indicated to identify the source of the infection. CT of the abdomen and pelvis would be a reasonable next test, looking for metastatic abscesses in the liver, spleen, and kidneys. Similarly, if the patient reports back pain or if no other focus has been identified, an MRI of the spine could be performed to investigate whether a spinal epidural abscess is present. Additional imaging techniques, such as cardiac CT or18 F-fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography with CT (FDG PET-CT), are also sometimes considered if the TEE is unrevealing.

Key learning point: The best diagnostic test for suspected infective endocarditis is a transesophageal echocardiogram.

B) INCORRECT:
