Lysis-centrifugation blood cultures increase the sensitivity for intracellular organisms and are not of use in managing infection due to S. aureus.

C) INCORRECT:

If the TEE is negative in a patient with MRSA bacteremia and ongoing fever, additional aggressive investigation is indicated to identify the source of the infection. CT of the abdomen and pelvis would be a reasonable next test, looking for metastatic abscesses in the liver, spleen, and kidneys.

D) INCORRECT:

If the TEE is negative in a patient with MRSA bacteremia and ongoing fever, additional aggressive investigation is indicated to identify the source of the infection. CT of the abdomen and pelvis would be a reasonable next test, looking for metastatic abscesses in the liver, spleen, and kidneys. Similarly, if the patient reports back pain or if no other focus has been identified, MRI of the spine could be performed to investigate whether a spinal epidural abscess is present.

E) INCORRECT:

In general, tagged white-blood-cell nuclear scans are only performed after standard imaging is negative.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man is hospitalized with a 4-week history of fevers, chills, night sweats, and weight loss. He has no known medical history.
His temperature is 38.5°C, his heart rate is 115 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg.
Laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range



Leukocyte count (per mm3)
14,500
4500–11,000



Hemoglobin (g/dL)
11.1
13.5–17.5


Platelet count (per mm3)
105,000
150,000–350,000


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.8
0.8–1.3


His other routine chemistry studies are in the normal range.
An echocardiogram is negative for valvular vegetations.
His blood cultures grow Streptococcus gallolyticus subsp. gallolyticus (formerly known as Streptococcus bovis biotype I) on hospital day 2.
Which one of the following additional studies is indicated next in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cystoscopy, positron emission tomography, tagged white-cell scan, and HIV testing are not routinely indicated in the evaluation of a S. gallolyticus bloodstream infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Cystoscopy, positron emission tomography, tagged white-cell scan, and HIV testing are not routinely indicated in the evaluation of a S. gallolyticus bloodstream infection.

C) CORRECT:

There is a strong association between infections with Streptococcus gallolyticus subsp. gallolyticus (formerly known as Streptococcus bovis biotype I) and colonic neoplasms. Therefore, evaluation of the gastrointestinal tract with colonoscopy is indicated for all patients with S. gallolyticus bloodstream infections.

S. gallolyticus is a gram-positive coccus that can cause bloodstream infections and infective endocarditis, usually from a gastrointestinal portal. Evaluation of the heart valves with an echocardiogram is warranted in patients with S. gallolyticus bacteremia. A S. gallolyticus bloodstream infection is generally treated with ceftriaxone, vancomycin, or penicillin, depending on the minimum inhibitory concentration of the organism.

Key learning point: The additional diagnostic testing indicated in patients with Streptococcus gallolyticus subsp. gallolyticus (formerly known as Streptococcus bovis biotype I) bloodstream infections is colonoscopy, given the strong association between Streptococcus gallolyticus subsp. gallolyticus infections and colorectal cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Cystoscopy, positron emission tomography, tagged white-cell scan, and HIV testing are not routinely indicated in the evaluation of a S. gallolyticus bloodstream infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Cystoscopy, positron emission tomography, tagged white-cell scan, and HIV testing are not routinely indicated in the evaluation of a S. gallolyticus bloodstream infection.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 4-day history of progressive dyspnea. His wife reports that he has had intermittent fevers and lethargy for almost 3 weeks, starting several days after he had his first dental cleaning in several years. She states that he has no known cardiac disease but that he has a heart murmur from an infection he contracted as a child growing up in Honduras.
On examination, his temperature is 38.4°C, his heart rate is 110 beats per minute, and he is tachypneic. He has a low, rumbling diastolic murmur and a loud holosystolic murmur.
An electrocardiogram reveals sinus tachycardia without heart block. A transthoracic echocardiogram does not show a vegetation. Two blood culture bottles are positive for gram-positive cocci in chains.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient's evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dilated funduscopic examination is not helpful because even if it were normal, it would not rule out endocarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

C-reactive protein is a nonspecific marker of infection and inflammation; its measurement is unlikely to be diagnostically informative in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The presentation in this case is not typical of acute rheumatic fever, so measurement of an antistreptolysin O titer to assess for a recent group A streptococcus pharyngitis is not indicated. Acute rheumatic fever can manifest with arthritis, carditis, chorea, erythema marginatum, and subcutaneous nodules.

D) CORRECT:

Transesophageal echocardiogram is the best diagnostic test for infective endocarditis, as it is more sensitive and specific than a transthoracic echocardiogram. Infective endocarditis can be diagnosed using the 2023 Duke-ISCVID criteria, which are a recent update of the modified Duke criteria. Diagnosis of definite infective endocarditis requires two major clinical criteria; a combination of one major criterion with three minor criteria; or five minor criteria.

Major criteria include:

• Microbiologic confirmation with either:
- Two blood cultures; PCR, amplicon, or metagenomic sequencing; or in situ hybridization identifying a typical organism seen in endocarditis
- A single positive blood culture or serologic or PCR evidence of Coxiella burnetii, Bartonella species , or Tropheryma whipplei infection
• Evidence of endocardial involvement on echocardiogram, cardiac CT, or integrated positron emission tomography and CT (PET/CT) or noted intraopteratively

Minor criteria include:

• Conditions predisposing toward endocarditis (e.g., predisposing heart condition, prior diagnosis of infective endocarditis, injection-drug use)
• Fever >38.0°C
• Vascular phenomena including splenic and cerebral abscesses
• Immunologic phenomena such as glomerulonephritis
• Microbiological evidence not satisfying a major criterion

Key learning point: In addition to blood cultures, the preferred diagnostic test for patients with a high suspicion of infective endocarditis is transesophageal echocardiogram.

E) INCORRECT:

A tagged white-cell scan is sometimes used when looking for occult infections, but it would not be indicated in this setting, given the high suspicion for endocarditis.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man with a history of end-stage kidney disease on hemodialysis and an aortic valve replacement 2 years ago presents with intermittent fevers. Recent blood cultures grew methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus. The patient had his hemodialysis catheter removed from his right subclavian vein and then started treatment with intravenous vancomycin, but he remains intermittently febrile.
A transesophageal echocardiogram reveals a small vegetation on his prosthetic aortic valve.
In addition to referral for cardiac surgery evaluation, which one of the following treatment regimens is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Intravenous ceftriaxone for 6 weeks with intravenous gentamicin for 2 weeks
Nafcillin and rifampin for 6 weeks with intravenous gentamicin for 2 weeks
Intravenous vancomycin after hemodialysis for 6 weeks with gentamicin after hemodialysis for 2 weeks
Intravenous vancomycin and rifampin for 6 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is not an appropriate drug for methicillin-susceptible S. aureus prosthetic-valve endocarditis.

B) CORRECT:

Appropriate therapy for methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus prosthetic-valve endocarditis is a penicillinase-resistant penicillin such as nafcillin 12 g daily for at least 6 weeks (oxacillin or cefazolin can also be used), in combination with 300 mg of rifampin 3 times daily. Rifampin is added with the hope of penetrating biofilm on the valve tissue. Intravenous gentamicin should also be included for synergy for the first 2 weeks.

All patients with prosthetic-valve endocarditis should undergo evaluation for cardiac surgery. Patients within one year of valve replacement are at high risk for complications such as severe valvular disease and myocardial abscesses.

Key learning point: The appropriate antibiotic management for methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus prosthetic-valve endocarditis is a combination of nafcillin, rifampin, and gentamicin.

C) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin would be appropriate as a substitute for nafcillin in patients with severe penicillin allergy. The goal trough is 15 to 20 μg/mL.

D) INCORRECT:

Nafcillin alone is not appropriate treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Appropriate therapy for methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus prosthetic-valve endocarditis is a penicillinase-resistant penicillin such as nafcillin 12 g daily for at least 6 weeks (oxacillin or cefazolin can also be used), in combination with 300 mg of rifampin 3 times daily. Rifampin is added with the hope of penetrating biofilm on the valve tissue. Intravenous gentamicin should also be included for synergy for the first 2 weeks.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man reports 6 weeks of fatigue, 1 week of low-grade fevers, and 4 months of an itchy rash on his arms and legs. He notes that his wife recently had an upper respiratory tract infection. His medical history is significant for a mechanical valve replacement one year ago for a bicuspid aortic valve that was complicated by severe aortic stenosis.
He has a heart rate of 100 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 98/56 mm Hg, and a temperature of 37.8°C. He appears fatigued but in no acute distress. He is slightly tachycardic without an obvious murmur. His lungs are clear to auscultation, his abdomen is soft and nontender, and he has no lower-extremity edema. He has a pustular rash on his arms and legs with excoriations.
Laboratory testing reveals a leukocyte count of 16,500 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000), a hemoglobin level of 15 g/dL (13.5–17.5), and a platelet count of 400,000 per mm3 (150,000–350,000). Urinalysis results are normal.
Blood cultures show growth of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus in both the aerobic and anaerobic bottles.
A transthoracic echocardiogram reveals no obvious valvular vegetations.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Skin biopsy would help to identify the cause of this patient’s rash, and his itching and excoriations might be the nidus for bacteremia. However, this test would not be diagnostic for endocarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Positron emission tomography (PET) is often used to identify IE when clinical suspicion remains high despite unrevealing echocardiographic imaging. However, this patient has not yet undergone standard, guideline-recommended testing, including a TEE.

C) CORRECT:

In a patient with a prosthetic heart valve, the combination of fever and leukocytosis should raise concern for infective endocarditis (IE). In addition, in this patient, the presence of Staphylococcus aureus in both blood cultures greatly increases the likelihood of IE. Guidelines from the American Heart Association recommend initial evaluation with a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE); if clinical suspicion remains high but this test is unrevealing, it should be followed by a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE).

Key learning point: In a patient with a mechanical aortic valve, a high suspicion for infectious endocarditis, and an unremarkable transthoracic echocardiogram, the most appropriate next diagnostic test is a transesophageal echocardiogram.

D) INCORRECT:

The erythrocyte sedimentation rate is a sensitive but nonspecific measure of inflammation. It can be used in the evaluation of suspected endocarditis but is not diagnostic for this condition.

E) INCORRECT:

CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis may be pursued in a patient with fever of unknown origin; however, endocarditis should be excluded as a diagnosis before a broader investigation is initiated.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of persistent fevers, night sweats, and diminished appetite for the past week. He has also been coming home from school tired and has missed several days of baseball practice. His history is significant for aortic stenosis that was diagnosed at birth and repaired surgically with placement of a prosthetic aortic valve when he was a toddler. Since the surgery, he has been growing and developing normally.
On physical examination, he has a temperature of 39.4°C, a heart rate of 123 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and a blood pressure of 103/63 mm Hg. He appears fatigued but is sitting comfortably on the bed. The first and second heart sounds are heard, as well as a systolic 3/4 harsh murmur that radiates to the neck. His abdomen is nontender and nondistended, his splenic edge is 4 cm below the costal margin, and his liver is not palpable. Small erythematous, nontender, nonblanching lesions are evident on his hands.
Blood cultures are ordered, and an echocardiogram is obtained that reveals a new partial dehiscence of the patient’s aortic valve. Acetaminophen is given for the fever.
Which one of the following antibiotic regimens is the best empiric therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin is a bacteriostatic agent and is therefore not recommended in the setting of infective endocarditis; in addition, it does not provide adequate coverage for S. aureus or for some of the HACEK organisms.

B) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone provides broad gram-negative and streptococcal coverage with some coverage of S. aureus, but it does not cover enterococci at all.

C) INCORRECT:

Piperacillin-tazobactam provides excellent gram-negative coverage, specifically for resistant gram-negative organisms such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa, but this regimen is not typically indicated in prosthetic valve endocarditis except in the setting of injection-drug use.

D) INCORRECT:

Empiric treatment of infective endocarditis should provide coverage for the most common causative organisms, which includes Viridans streptococci, Staphylococcus aureus, coagulase-negative staphylococci, beta-hemolytic streptococci, and enterococci. Levofloxacin is not an appropriate empiric treatment option for infective endocarditis.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with high fevers, night sweats, fatigue, and diminished appetite, which is concerning for a systemic illness. He also has a prosthetic aortic valve, which puts him at an increased risk for infective endocarditis.

Infective endocarditis can be diagnosed using the 2023 Duke-ISCVID criteria, which are a recent update of the modified Duke criteria.

Major criteria include:

• Microbiologic confirmation with either:
- Two blood cultures; PCR, amplicon, or metagenomic sequencing; or in situ hybridization identifying a typical organism seen in endocarditis
- A single positive blood culture or serologic or PCR evidence of Coxiella burnetii, Bartonella species , or Tropheryma whipplei infection
• Evidence of endocardial involvement on echocardiogram, cardiac CT, or integrated positron emission tomography and CT (PET/CT) or noted intraopteratively

Minor criteria include:

• Conditions predisposing toward endocarditis (e.g., predisposing heart condition, prior diagnosis of infective endocarditis, injection-drug use)
• Fever >38.0°C
• Vascular phenomena including splenic and cerebral abscesses
• Immunologic phenomena such as glomerulonephritis
• Microbiological evidence not satisfying a major criterion

A definitive diagnosis requires two major criteria, a combination of one major criterion and three minor criteria, or five minor criteria. This patient has one major criterion (new partial dehiscence on echocardiogram) and three minor criteria (fever, vascular phenomena, and predisposing heart condition) and can thus be diagnosed with infective endocarditis.

Treating Infective Endocarditis

Empiric treatment of infective endocarditis should provide coverage for the most common causative organisms: Viridans streptococci, Staphylococcus aureus, coagulase-negative staphylococci, beta-hemolytic streptococci, and enterococci. Less frequently, one of the HACEK organisms (Haemophilus species, Aggregatibacter species, Cardiobacterium hominis, Eikenella corrodens, or Kingella) is the cause of infective endocarditis. The most common fungal cause of endocarditis is the Candida species.

The combination of ampicillin-sulbactam and gentamicin targets both streptococci and methicillin-susceptible staphylococci. In patients with prosthetic valves, rifampin can be added as adjunctive therapy for S. aureus, especially if valve replacement occurred < 1 year before infection. An alternative regimen for empiric treatment of native valve endocarditis or late prosthetic valve endocarditis is vancomycin plus gentamicin, which will cover the above-mentioned organisms, including methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA). This regimen, including vancomycin, is recommended for patients with infective endocarditis in the first year after surgery, as coagulase-negative staphylococci are often implicated in these cases.

Modification of antibiotic therapy and long-term treatment should be determined by culture results and sensitivities.

Key learning point: A child with a prosthetic aortic valve who presents with fevers, night sweats, and fatigue should be treated empirically with ampicillin-sulbactam and gentamicin.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old girl presents to the emergency department after 10 days of high fevers, diminished appetite, fatigue, and intermittent arm and leg pain. Her parents report that during the past few days, she has also had a rash on her hands and feet.
On examination, she has a temperature of 39.1°C, a heart rate of 113 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and a blood pressure of 110/45 mm Hg. Since her last visit to her primary care provider 3 months ago, she has lost 1.5 kg. She has a new systolic murmur heard best in the left lower border, her breath sounds are clear, and her abdomen is soft and nondistended. She has a few scattered erythematous, nonblanching, circular lesions on her hands and soles.
Urinalysis reveals microscopic hematuria. Initial screening tests, including a complete blood count and basic metabolic panel, are ordered.
Which one of the following tests is most likely to establish the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although testing for cardiac troponins and B-type natriuretic peptide levels may help to identify ischemia and assess heart failure, it will not provide a diagnosis of endocarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Although testing for cardiac troponins and B-type natriuretic peptide levels may help to identify ischemia and assess heart failure, it will not provide a diagnosis of endocarditis.

C) INCORRECT:

A respiratory viral panel would not be helpful in identifying the potential pathogen in this case.

D) CORRECT:

This patient presents with high fevers, myalgias, petechiae, and hematuria, which are together concerning for a systemic illness. She also has a new cardiac murmur. Her constellation of symptoms and its indolent presentation raise suspicion for infective endocarditis.

The clinical findings in infective endocarditis are related to four phenomena: bacteremia (or fungemia), valvulitis, immunologic response, and emboli. In children, symptoms are indolent and include fever, malaise, arthralgia, and anorexia. Children rarely have late signs of infective endocarditis, such as splinter hemorrhages, retinal hemorrhages (Roth spots), hemorrhagic lesions on the palms and soles (Janeway lesions), and intradermal nodules on the fingers and toes (Osler nodes).

Infective endocarditis can be diagnosed using the 2023 Duke-ISCVID criteria, which are a recent update of the modified Duke criteria.

Major criteria include:

• Microbiologic confirmation with either:
- Two blood cultures; PCR, amplicon, or metagenomic sequencing; or in situ hybridization identifying a typical organism seen in endocarditis
- A single positive blood culture or serologic or PCR evidence of Coxiella burnetii, Bartonella species, or Tropheryma whipplei infection
• Evidence of endocardial involvement on echocardiogram, cardiac CT, or integrated positron emission tomography and CT (PET/CT) or noted intraopteratively

Minor criteria include:

• Conditions predisposing toward endocarditis (e.g., predisposing heart condition, prior diagnosis of infective endocarditis, injection-drug use)
• Fever > 38.0°C
• Vascular phenomena including splenic and cerebral abscesses
• Immunologic phenomena such as glomerulonephritis
• Microbiological evidence not satisfying a major criterion

A definitive diagnosis of infective endocarditis requires two major criteria, a combination of one major criterion with three minor criteria, or five minor criteria. At the present time, this patient meets three of the five minor criteria (fever plus vascular phenomena [Janeway lesions] and immunologic phenomena [hematuria]) but has not yet had a microbiologic test or imaging to evaluate for major criteria. Blood cultures and cardiac imaging should therefore be obtained. Empiric antibiotics should be started after the blood cultures are collected.

Key learning point: The most appropriate diagnostic test for a child with a prolonged course of fevers who has vascular and immunologic phenomena that raise concern for infective endocarditis is a blood culture in addition to cardiac imaging.

E) INCORRECT:

A urine culture would not be helpful in identifying the potential pathogen in this case.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl who was born in Mexico and has a visible incisional sternal scar is referred by her dentist for evaluation before urgent dental work and cleaning. Her parents report that she was followed in the past by a pediatric cardiologist, but they haven't seen that provider for several years. They are not sure what her diagnosis is, but they know that she was "blue when she was born" and required two heart surgeries — one shortly after birth and another a couple of months later. She currently takes a multivitamin with iron and recently reached menarche. She has no known drug allergies.
The patient is currently afebrile. Her blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg in the right arm and 120/80 mm Hg in the left arm. She has a regular heart rate at 75 beats per minute and an oxygen saturation of 84% while breathing ambient air.
She has a normal first heart sound; a fixed, split second heart sound; a right parasternal heave; and a soft, early diastolic decrescendo murmur, best appreciated over the left lower sternal border. She has no lower-extremity edema. Her right radial pulse is diminished compared with her left.
In addition to referring this patient for further cardiac evaluation, which one of the following recommendations is most appropriate with respect to the dental procedure?

choices.text: Prescribe cephalexin 2 g by mouth the morning of the procedure
Prescribe ampicillin 2 g intravenously 4 hours before the procedure
Prescribe clindamycin 600 mg by mouth the night before the procedure
Prescribe amoxicillin 2 g by mouth one hour before the procedure

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin, cephalexin, clarithromycin, and doxycycline are acceptable alternatives if the patient is allergic to amoxicillin and can tolerate these agents.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has cyanotic congenital heart disease from birth and does not appear to have had a complete repair. The decreased blood pressure on the right arm compared with the left, the low oxygen saturation, and the murmur suggest that she had a Blalock-Taussig shunt. In addition to referral to a pediatric cardiologist, she should receive endocarditis prophylaxis before dental procedures, including routine cleanings.

C) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular or intravenous ampicillin, cefazolin, and ceftriaxone are acceptable alternatives if the patient cannot tolerate an antibiotic by mouth.

D) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin is no longer recommended as prophylaxis for infective endocarditis because it is associated with higher rates of Clostridioides difficile infection and potential complications from such infection.

E) CORRECT:

The American Heart Association guidelines for antibiotic prophylaxis during dental procedures are targeted toward the group of patients deemed to be at greatest risk for infective endocarditis:

• Patients who have prosthetic cardiac valves, including transcatheter-implanted prostheses and homografts
• Patients who have prosthetic material used for cardiac valve repair, such as annuloplasty rings and chords
• Patients with previous infective endocarditis
• Patients with unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease or repaired congenital heart disease, with residual shunts or valvular regurgitation at the site of or adjacent to the site of a prosthetic patch or prosthetic device
• Patients who have a cardiac transplant with valve regurgitation due to a structurally abnormal valve

This patient has cyanotic congenital heart disease from birth and does not appear to have had a complete repair. The decreased blood pressure on the right arm compared with the left, the low oxygen saturation, and the murmur suggest that she had a Blalock-Taussig shunt. In addition to referral to a pediatric cardiologist, she should receive endocarditis prophylaxis before dental procedures, including routine cleanings.

In all patients without known drug allergies who can tolerate oral medications, the most appropriate antibiotic for endocarditis prophylaxis before a dental procedure is amoxicillin. Antibiotic prophylaxis should be taken 30 to 60 minutes before the procedure.

Key learning point: When indicated, the antibiotic of choice for the prevention of endocarditis in a patient having a dental procedure is amoxicillin.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl is brought in for a routine well-child examination. She was adopted from an orphanage in China, has a history of unrepaired congenital heart disease, and is regularly followed by a cardiologist. She had otitis media 6 months ago and vomited immediately after her first dose of amoxicillin but has otherwise been healthy. She is preparing for her first trip to the dentist.
On examination, her weight is 11.5 kg, and her height is 87 cm. Her heart rate is 100 beats per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 86% while she breathes ambient air. She is in no distress.
Cardiac examination reveals a 3/6 crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard loudest at the left upper sternal border, with radiation to the axillae bilaterally. Lung examination reveals good air entry bilaterally, with normal breath sounds and no increased work of breathing. The abdomen is soft with no organomegaly. Examination of the hands and feet reveals moderate clubbing with no edema.
Which one of the following antibiotics, if any, should be prescribed for this patient before her upcoming dental cleaning?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has evidence of cyanotic congenital heart disease. Although the exact diagnosis is unknown, a pulmonary stenosis murmur with cyanosis is consistent with tetralogy of Fallot. Given this condition, she should receive antibiotic prophylaxis before her dental cleaning, to help prevent infective endocarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin is no longer recommended as prophylaxis for infective endocarditis because it is associated with higher rates of Clostridioides difficile infection and potential complications from such infection.

C) INCORRECT:

The preferred medication for infective endocarditis prophylaxis in children who require it before dental procedures is amoxicillin 50 mg/kg, given by mouth in a single dose 30 to 60 minutes before the procedure. For patients with an amoxicillin allergy, options include cephalexin, azithromycin, clarithromycin, and doxycycline. Although this patient previously had an episode of emesis after taking an oral dose of amoxicillin, there was no evidence of an allergic reaction, so amoxicillin would be the preferred medication.

D) INCORRECT:

If a patient cannot tolerate oral medications, the intravenous or intramuscular options for antibiotic prophylaxis include ampicillin and ceftriaxone. This patient can take oral medications, so amoxicillin is the best choice for her.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has evidence of cyanotic congenital heart disease. Although the exact diagnosis is unknown, a pulmonary stenosis murmur with cyanosis is consistent with tetralogy of Fallot. Given this condition, she should receive antibiotic prophylaxis before her dental cleaning, to help prevent infective endocarditis.

Antibiotic Prophylaxis for Infective Endocarditis

According to current American Heart Association guidelines for the prevention of infective endocarditis, antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated for select groups of patients before they undergo certain dental procedures (those that involve manipulation of gingival tissue, manipulation of the periapical region of teeth, or perforation of the oral mucosa), including dental cleanings.

• Any patient with a history of infective endocarditis requires antibiotic prophylaxis in this setting, as do patients with a prosthetic heart valve and those with a history of heart transplantation and subsequent valvular disease.
• Certain patients with congenital heart disease — including those who have unrepaired cyanotic disease or repaired congenital heart disease with a residual defect — also require antibiotic prophylaxis.
• Patients with completely repaired congenital heart disease who have prosthetic material in place require antibiotic prophylaxis for the first 6 months after the cardiac procedure.

Choosing an Appropriate Antibiotic

The preferred medication for infective endocarditis prophylaxis in children who require it before dental procedures is amoxicillin 50 mg/kg, given by mouth in a single dose 30 to 60 minutes before the procedure. For patients with an amoxicillin allergy, options include cephalexin, azithromycin, clarithromycin, and doxycycline. Although this patient previously had an episode of emesis after taking an oral dose of amoxicillin, there was no evidence of an allergic reaction, so amoxicillin would be the preferred medication.

If a patient cannot tolerate oral medications, the intravenous or intramuscular options for antibiotic prophylaxis include ampicillin and ceftriaxone.

Key learning point: In a child with unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease who is about to undergo a dental cleaning, the most appropriate medication for infective endocarditis prophylaxis is amoxicillin 50 mg/kg, given once by mouth 30 to 60 minutes before the cleaning.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to discuss her dentist's recommendation that she take antibiotics before routine dental cleanings. About 10 years ago, she had an echocardiogram that showed mitral valve prolapse. Currently, she has no physical complaints; she exercises regularly and has no exertional dyspnea or chest pain. Her physical examination reveals a midsystolic click at the lower left sternal border and apex; the examination is otherwise normal. How should you counsel this patient with regard to preventing infective endocarditis?

choices.text: Repeat the echocardiogram and then make the decision about antibiotic prophylaxis
Explain that antibiotics are not warranted

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin lacks reliable activity against oral streptococci and is therefore not an appropriate choice for prophylaxis before dental procedures, even for patients who meet criteria for prophylaxis.

B) INCORRECT:

Repeating an echocardiogram is unnecessary in this case; the patient is asymptomatic, her examination is consistent with the previous diagnosis of mitral valve prolapse, and there is no plausible echocardiographic finding that would change the decision to avoid antibiotic prophylaxis.

C) INCORRECT:

In patients who do require antibiotic prophylaxis, oral amoxicillin is the preferred treatment. Cephalexin, azithromycin, clarithromycin, or doxycycline may be used if the patient has a penicillin allergy. Caution should be exercised with the use of macrolide antibiotics in patients who are predisposed to develop a prolonged corrected QT (QTc) interval, such as those who have baseline QTc prolongation and those who are taking medications that either also prolong the QTc interval or inhibit cytochrome P-450 3A4 enzymes (e.g., antifungal medications, diltiazem, verapamil, and amiodarone).

D) CORRECT:

According to 2020 guidelines from the American Heart Association, patients undergoing dental procedures that involve manipulation of gingival tissue, manipulation of the periapical region of teeth, or perforation of the oral mucosa should receive antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis if they have any of the following cardiac conditions:

• Prosthetic cardiac valves, including transcatheter-implanted prostheses and homografts
• Prosthetic material used for cardiac valve repair, such as annuloplasty rings and chords
• Previous infective endocarditis
• Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease or repaired congenital heart disease, with residual shunts or valvular regurgitation at the site of or adjacent to the site of a prosthetic patch or prosthetic device
• Cardiac transplant with valve regurgitation due to a structurally abnormal valve

This patient does not have any of the conditions listed above and therefore does not require antibiotic prophylaxis in this setting. The estimated absolute risk for infective endocarditis from a dental procedure in patients with mitral valve prolapse is 1 per 1.1 million procedures.

Key learning point: Patients with asymptomatic mitral valve prolapses do not need to receive antibiotic prophylaxis before a dental cleaning.

E) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin is no longer recommended for prophylaxis due to higher rates of Clostridioides difficile infection.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency room because of a 5-day history of high fever and fatigue. Her mother says that the child has also complained about pain in her arms and legs for the past 3 days. Her temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), pulse is 128/min, and blood pressure is 96/52 mm Hg. A grade 3/6 systolic murmur is heard at the apex. Abdominal examination shows splenomegaly. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.8 g/dL


Leukocyte count
16,300/mm3


Platelet count
220,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
50 mm/h


Urine



 Protein

2+


 RBC

10/hpf


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous vancomycin is the empiric treatment of choice for acute IE, as it is effective against the most common causative organisms (staphylococci and viridans streptococci). However, a different intervention should precede the start of empiric antibiotic therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

An antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is used as a screening test for several autoimmune diseases including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). SLE can manifest with fever, fatigue, arthralgia, splenomegaly, glomerulonephritis, and elevated ESR. A rare complication of SLE is Libman-Sacks endocarditis, which can manifest with a new-onset murmur. Instead of acute febrile disease, however, patients with SLE most commonly present with anorexia, fatigue, and a low-grade fever that is gradual in onset. Moreover, cytopenia with leukopenia rather than leukocytosis is seen in SLE. Finally, this condition is rare in children under the age of 5 years.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal biopsy may be necessary in patients with glomerulonephritis (GN) without an apparent cause or in the case of suspected rapidly progressive GN. This patient's GN occurred in the setting of acute IE; a renal biopsy is not indicated at this point.

D) CORRECT:

In a patient with suspected IE, a minimum of three blood cultures from different venipuncture sites should be obtained as soon as possible and over a short period of time (e.g., < 1 hour in acutely ill patients). The presence of bacteria typical for IE (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus) obtained from two separate blood cultures is a major Duke criterion. Because patients with IE usually have continuous bacteremia, blood cultures are positive in a high percentage of cases. Blood cultures should always be collected before initiating antibiotic therapy, so as to avoid potentially false-negative results.

E) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid factor (RF) is a nonspecific inflammatory marker that may be elevated in patients with autoimmune or infectious diseases. Although RF is part of the minor diagnostic criteria of IE indicating immunologic phenomena, another, more appropriate step, must first be taken.
questions.hint: This previously healthy child presents with high fever, arthralgia, a new-onset murmur, and splenomegaly. In combination with leukocytosis, an elevated ESR, and signs of glomerulonephritis (RBCs and mild proteinuria on urinalysis), these findings suggest acute infective endocarditis (IE).

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents with a two-week history of intermittent fevers and fatigue. He underwent a dental extraction eight days ago and has a history of rheumatic fever in his teenage years. Examination reveals a new holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex and mild splenomegaly. He denies chest pain, joint swelling, rashes, or shortness of breath. He notes mild flank discomfort but no flank pain. There are no skin petechiae on examination (see lab results and reports).

Temperature
38.4°C



Test
Result
Normal Values



Urine




 Erythrocytes
12 per high power field
0 - 2 per high power field


 RBC casts
Occasional
Absent




ECG: Sinus tachycardia
Blood cultures: Pending result

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pericarditis typically presents with sharp, pleuritic chest pain, a pericardial friction rub, and diffuse ST-segment changes on ECG, none of which are noted. The new holosystolic murmur and renal findings suggest valvular involvement and embolic phenomena, not pericardial inflammation. The recent dental extraction and past rheumatic fever history point to valvular infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Rheumatic heart disease results from chronic valvular damage due to an immune response following group A streptococcal pharyngitis. It typically manifests years later with thickened, calcified valves and a history of migratory arthritis. The acute presentation of fever, fatigue, a new murmur, and renal abnormalities suggests an infective process rather than chronic valvular degeneration.

C) CORRECT:

Infective endocarditis manifests with symptoms such as intermittent fevers, fatigue, and a new holosystolic murmur, often following procedures like dental extractions that introduce bacteria into the bloodstream. Individuals with a history of rheumatic fever have damaged valvular endocardium, making them susceptible to bacterial colonization, particularly by viridans streptococci. The presence of splenomegaly and renal findings, such as hematuria and red blood cell casts, suggests systemic embolization and immune complex deposition. These findings indicate bacterial colonization on the valve, leading to vegetations and multisystem involvement.

Key learning point: In patients with a history of rheumatic fever and recent dental procedures, the presence of fever, a new or changing heart murmur, splenomegaly, and hematuria is highly suggestive of bacterial endocarditis.

D) INCORRECT:

Myocarditis often presents with chest pain, dyspnea, arrhythmias, or heart failure, none of which are present. The new holosystolic murmur suggests valvular involvement, not myocardial inflammation. Renal findings indicate embolic or immune complex injury, not typical of myocarditis. The recent dental procedure aligns more with valvular infection.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old man presents with 2 weeks of progressive fatigue, low-grade fevers, and unintentional weight loss. He has no significant past medical history and reports no urinary symptoms or recent hospitalizations. He notes frequent gum bleeding due to poor dentition. Physical examination reveals a new blowing holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex. Blood cultures are pending.
Which organism is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Streptococcus viridans, a group of alpha-hemolytic bacteria, commonly colonizes the oral cavity and is associated with subacute infective endocarditis, especially in individuals with poor dentition or following dental procedures. These bacteria adhere to preexisting valvular lesions or damaged endothelium, forming vegetations. The patient's symptoms of low-grade fever, fatigue, weight loss, and a new holosystolic murmur align with S. viridans-induced endocarditis. The organism's ability to colonize sites of minor endothelial injury in cardiac valves underscores its role in endocarditis linked to chronic poor oral hygiene.

Key learning point: In subacute infective endocarditis, Streptococcus viridans are the most common causative organisms, especially in the presence of poor oral hygiene or following dental procedures.

B) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus species, part of the HACEK group, can cause subacute endocarditis and are found in the oropharyngeal flora. However, the patient's chronic course and poor dental hygiene are more typical of endocarditis caused by other oral flora. HACEK organisms are less common and often require specialized culture conditions, which are not indicated here.

C) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus faecalis often causes endocarditis in patients with genitourinary procedures or urinary tract conditions. This patient lacks urinary symptoms or recent urologic manipulation, which are key risk factors for enterococcal infection. The presence of poor dentition and gum bleeding suggests an oral source of bacteremia, making Enterococcus faecalis less likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus typically causes acute infective endocarditis with high-grade fevers and rapid deterioration, often linked to intravenous drug use or indwelling catheters. The patient's subacute presentation with low-grade fevers and poor dentition suggests an oral source, making S. aureus less consistent with the observed clinical course.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man presents with one week of fever, chills, and malaise. He has no significant medical history. Physical examination reveals a new holosystolic murmur at the apex, several painless erythematous lesions on his palms, and tender nodules on his fingertips. Blood cultures are obtained.

Temperature
38.6°C

Echocardiography: Vegetations on the mitral valve
Which of the following intravenous regimens is the most appropriate initial empirical treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nafcillin targets methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA), and gentamicin provides synergistic bactericidal effects. However, this combination lacks coverage for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and other common pathogens in native valve endocarditis. Empirical therapy requires broader coverage, including MRSA and viridans group streptococci.

B) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone covers many Streptococcus species, and gentamicin enhances bactericidal activity against certain streptococci. However, this regimen lacks reliable coverage for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), a significant pathogen in infective endocarditis. Broad empirical coverage, including MRSA, is crucial until culture results are available.

C) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin covers methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus and other gram-positive organisms. However, piperacillin-tazobactam is more suited for gram-negative organisms and anaerobes, not the primary pathogens in native valve endocarditis. Additionally, this combination increases nephrotoxicity risk, especially with prolonged therapy.

D) CORRECT:

Vancomycin plus ceftriaxone provides broad-spectrum coverage for suspected infective endocarditis on a native valve with pending culture results. Vancomycin covers gram-positive organisms, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and coagulase-negative staphylococci. Ceftriaxone covers streptococci, including viridans group streptococci, and HACEK organisms, common in community-acquired native valve endocarditis. This empirical regimen addresses likely pathogens until culture data allow for targeted therapy.

Key learning point: Empirical therapy for suspected infective endocarditis should cover common organisms including Streptococci, Staphylococci, and Enterococci, with ceftriaxone and vancomycin being a suitable combination.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man presents with two weeks of intermittent fevers, night sweats, and fatigue. He has a 5-year history of intravenous heroin use. Examination reveals a harsh holosystolic murmur along the left lower sternal border that intensifies with inspiration. Multiple small, painless, red macules are noted on his palms, and thin brownish streaks are present beneath several fingernails. Blood cultures are pending.


Heart rate
100/min


Temperature
38.6°C


Which organism is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa can cause infective endocarditis, especially in hospital settings or with contaminated devices. However, the patient's subacute symptoms and classic endocarditis stigmata, such as Janeway lesions and splinter hemorrhages, are more typical of Staphylococcus aureus. The absence of hospital-related exposures further reduces the likelihood of Pseudomonas infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus viridans typically causes subacute infective endocarditis following dental procedures in individuals with preexisting valvular abnormalities, primarily affecting left-sided heart valves. The patient's history of intravenous drug use and the murmur suggestive of tricuspid regurgitation align more with right-sided endocarditis caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

C) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus epidermidis is associated with infections involving prosthetic devices due to its biofilm-forming ability. It is less likely in this patient, who has no prosthetic devices and presents with acute symptoms and signs of septic embolization from a native valve, which are more consistent with a virulent organism like Staphylococcus aureus.

D) CORRECT:

Intravenous drug users are at high risk for right-sided infective endocarditis, often involving the tricuspid valve. The harsh holosystolic murmur along the left lower sternal border that intensifies with inspiration suggests tricuspid regurgitation. Staphylococcus aureus is the most common pathogen in these cases due to its virulence factors that facilitate adherence to the endocardium and rapid tissue destruction. The presence of Janeway lesions and splinter hemorrhages indicates septic emboli, frequently seen in acute bacterial endocarditis caused by S. aureus. Blood cultures typically confirm the diagnosis by isolating this organism.

Key learning point: Bacterial endocarditis is characterized by fever, night sweats, and specific signs such as Janeway lesions, Roth spots, and splinter hemorrhages, especially in intravenous drug users.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents for assessment of an elective umbilical hernia repair. He has a mechanical aortic valve and takes warfarin, a beta-blocker, and a statin. His last cardiology evaluation three months ago showed stable valve function without evidence of infection. He has not had recent dental work or procedures.
He asks whether he needs antibiotic prophylaxis before surgery to prevent infective endocarditis. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding endocarditis prophylaxis for this procedure?

choices.text: Intravenous cefazolin specifically for endocarditis prevention
Oral amoxicillin 1 hour before the procedure

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous cefazolin is used for surgical site infection prophylaxis but not for endocarditis prevention. Endocarditis prophylaxis is recommended only for select dental procedures in patients with high-risk cardiac conditions. The umbilical hernia repair does not involve bacteremia types that predispose to endocarditis, making cefazolin for this purpose unwarranted.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin is used for endocarditis prophylaxis in dental procedures involving gingival tissue manipulation, where significant bacteremia is likely. However, elective umbilical hernia repair does not involve the oropharyngeal flora or predispose to bacteremia associated with dental interventions. Current guidelines restrict antibiotic prophylaxis to high-risk dental procedures, making this option inappropriate for abdominal surgery.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous vancomycin is reserved for patients with severe beta-lactam allergies undergoing dental procedures that require endocarditis prophylaxis. Elective umbilical hernia repair does not typically produce bacteremia associated with endocarditis risk. The patient's stable cardiac evaluation further supports that prophylaxis is unnecessary in this context.

D) CORRECT:

Patients with prosthetic heart valves are at increased risk for infective endocarditis, but current guidelines recommend antibiotic prophylaxis only for procedures likely to cause bacteremia with oral flora, such as dental procedures involving gingival tissue manipulation. Elective umbilical hernia repair does not involve such areas and does not warrant endocarditis prophylaxis. The risk of bacteremia leading to infective endocarditis during this procedure is minimal, and routine antibiotic use in low-risk settings could lead to unnecessary adverse effects without benefit.

Key learning point: Antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis is not recommended for non-dental procedures such as elective hernia repair, even in patients with a history of mechanical heart valve replacement.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man presents with increasing fatigue over the past 6 months to the clinic. He is a former smoker with well-controlled hypertension. Examination reveals a crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space, radiating to the carotids. His lungs are clear, and there is no peripheral edema (see report).

Blood pressure
138/82 mm Hg

Electrocardiogram: Normal sinus rhythm with mild left ventricular hypertrophy
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient’s murmur?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transesophageal echocardiography offers enhanced resolution of cardiac structures and is useful when transthoracic echocardiography is limited, such as in patients with poor acoustic windows. However, the patient's clinical presentation and murmur characteristics suggest a valvular process that can be effectively evaluated with a non-invasive transthoracic echocardiogram, making transesophageal echocardiography unnecessarily invasive at this stage.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization provides definitive hemodynamic measurements and coronary anatomy assessment but is invasive and not the first-line test for suspected valvular abnormalities. The patient's murmur and left ventricular hypertrophy suggest aortic stenosis, which is initially evaluated with transthoracic echocardiography. Cardiac catheterization is considered when non-invasive imaging is inconclusive or for coronary assessment before surgery.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac MRI provides excellent anatomic detail and myocardial tissue characterization but is not a first-line study for isolated valvular lesions. Transthoracic echocardiography is preferred for initial evaluation of aortic stenosis, as it provides real-time assessment of valve morphology, gradients, and left ventricular function. Cardiac MRI is reserved for cases with inadequate echocardiographic windows or when additional myocardial characterization is needed.

D) CORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiography is the preferred initial study for evaluating valvular heart disease. It noninvasively visualizes cardiac structures and provides detailed information about valve morphology and function. It assesses leaflet thickening, calcification, and reduced excursion, and determines stenosis severity by measuring transvalvular gradients and estimating orifice area via Doppler techniques. Additionally, it evaluates chamber sizes and left ventricular function, essential for understanding the hemodynamic impact of the valvular lesion. This comprehensive evaluation supports clinical management decisions in patients with suspected valvular pathology.

Key learning point: Echocardiography is the best initial diagnostic test for evaluating heart murmurs and assessing heart valve structure and function.

questions.text: An 8-year-old with repaired tetralogy of Fallot has mild fevers, malaise, and a new harsh holosystolic murmur for one week. Which next step is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immediate initiation of broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics can reduce the sensitivity of blood cultures, which are vital for identifying the pathogen and determining antibiotic susceptibilities. In a hemodynamically stable patient with mild symptoms, obtaining blood cultures and imaging studies before starting antibiotics is the standard approach.

B) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic antibiotics are used to prevent infections during specific invasive procedures in high-risk patients. They are not appropriate for addressing an active infection, such as suspected infective endocarditis, which requires immediate evaluation and management.

C) INCORRECT:

A chest radiograph is limited in evaluating intracardiac structures and cannot reliably identify vegetations or valvular regurgitation. While it can assess the cardiac silhouette and pulmonary parenchyma, it lacks the sensitivity and specificity needed for diagnosing endocarditis.

D) CORRECT:

In a child with repaired tetralogy of Fallot, the presence of mild fever, malaise, and a new holosystolic murmur suggests infective endocarditis. Repaired congenital heart defects can predispose to endocarditis due to residual turbulent flow and prosthetic material. Blood cultures are essential for identifying the causative organism and should be obtained before starting antibiotics to maximize diagnostic yield. A transthoracic echocardiogram is a non-invasive method to detect valvular vegetations and assess for complications like abscess formation, providing crucial information for diagnosis and management.

Key learning point: Ventricular septal defect and tetralogy of Fallot are congenital heart defects associated with a higher risk of developing endocarditis due to turbulent blood flow and potential for bacterial colonization.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman is scheduled for an elective total thyroidectomy. She has a 2-year history of mitral valve prolapse and mild mitral regurgitation, with no history of infective endocarditis or prosthetic heart valves. Her vital signs are stable, and physical examination shows no evidence of active infection. She is concerned about postoperative complications, particularly endocarditis.
Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding antibiotic prophylaxis?

choices.text: Oral dose of amoxicillin for endocarditis prophylaxis
Intravenous vancomycin due to her mitral valve disease

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Current guidelines recommend antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis only in patients with high-risk conditions, such as a history of infective endocarditis, prosthetic heart valves, or specific congenital heart defects. Patients with isolated mitral valve prolapse and mild regurgitation, without a history of endocarditis, do not require prophylaxis. Additionally, elective total thyroidectomy is not associated with significant bacteremia that would necessitate endocarditis prophylaxis. These guidelines aim to prevent unnecessary antibiotic use and reserve prophylaxis for those at significant risk.

Key learning point: In clean surgical procedures like thyroidectomy, antibiotic prophylaxis is not routinely indicated unless there are specific risk factors for infection, and mitral valve prolapse with mild regurgitation does not require endocarditis prophylaxis for non-dental procedures.

B) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin is used for endocarditis prophylaxis in high-risk patients undergoing certain dental procedures. However, this patient with mitral valve prolapse and mild regurgitation does not meet the criteria for prophylaxis. Elective thyroidectomy does not involve significant bacteremia, making amoxicillin unnecessary.

C) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin is not indicated for endocarditis prophylaxis in patients with mitral valve prolapse and mild regurgitation. Current guidelines reserve prophylaxis for high-risk conditions, such as a history of endocarditis or prosthetic valves. This patient's condition does not warrant vancomycin, and thyroidectomy is not a high-risk procedure for bacteremia.

D) INCORRECT:

Cefazolin is used for surgical site infection prophylaxis in clean procedures, targeting skin flora. However, the concern here is preventing infective endocarditis, not surgical site infection. Current guidelines restrict endocarditis prophylaxis to high-risk cardiac conditions, which this patient does not have. Elective thyroidectomy is not associated with significant bacteremia, making cefazolin unnecessary for endocarditis prevention.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to your clinic to discuss her dentist's recommendation to take antibiotics before routine dental cleanings. Ten years ago, she had an echocardiogram that showed mitral valve prolapse. She currently has no symptoms, exercises regularly, and reports no exertional dyspnea or chest pain. On examination, you note a midsystolic click at the lower left sternal border and apex; the rest of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate counselling regarding prevention of infective endocarditis?

choices.text: Repeat the echocardiogram and then make the decision about antibiotic prophylaxis.
Explain that antibiotics are not warranted.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin is no longer recommended for prophylaxis due to higher rates of Clostridioides difficile infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Repeating an echocardiogram is unnecessary in this case; the patient is asymptomatic, her examination is consistent with the previous diagnosis of mitral valve prolapse, and there is no plausible echocardiographic finding that would change the decision to avoid antibiotic prophylaxis.

C) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin lacks reliable activity against oral streptococci and is therefore not an appropriate choice for prophylaxis before dental procedures, even for patients who meet criteria for prophylaxis.

D) CORRECT:

According to 2020 guidelines from the American Heart Association, patients undergoing dental procedures that involve manipulation of gingival tissue, manipulation of the periapical region of teeth, or perforation of the oral mucosa should receive antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis if they have any of the following cardiac conditions:

• Prosthetic cardiac valves, including transcatheter-implanted prostheses and homografts
• Prosthetic material used for cardiac valve repair, such as annuloplasty rings and chords
• Previous infective endocarditis
• Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease or repaired congenital heart disease, with residual shunts or valvular regurgitation at the site of or adjacent to the site of a prosthetic patch or prosthetic device
• Cardiac transplant with valve regurgitation due to a structurally abnormal valve

This patient does not have any of the conditions listed above and therefore does not require antibiotic prophylaxis in this setting. The estimated absolute risk for infective endocarditis from a dental procedure in patients with mitral valve prolapse is 1 per 1.1 million procedures.

Key learning point: Patients with asymptomatic mitral valve prolapses do not need to receive antibiotic prophylaxis before a dental cleaning.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients who do require antibiotic prophylaxis, oral amoxicillin is the preferred treatment. Cephalexin, azithromycin, clarithromycin, or doxycycline may be used if the patient has a penicillin allergy. Caution should be exercised with the use of macrolide antibiotics in patients who are predisposed to develop a prolonged corrected QT (QTc) interval, such as those who have baseline QTc prolongation and those who are taking medications that either also prolong the QTc interval or inhibit cytochrome P-450 3A4 enzymes (e.g., antifungal medications, diltiazem, verapamil, and amiodarone).

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of fatigue and exertional shortness of breath, and a 10-day history of low-grade fever. He has a history of gingivitis but no other significant medical history. He does not use illicit drugs. On examination, you note a grade 2/6 systolic murmur at the right sternal border and second intercostal space and several splinter hemorrhages under his fingernails. Blood cultures are sent, and you initiate empiric intravenous vancomycin and ceftriaxone. The blood cultures grow gram-negative bacilli identified as Cardiobacterium hominis. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin, which is often used for empirical therapy in infective endocarditis, is highly effective against a wide range of gram-positive organisms. However, this antibiotic is ineffective against gram-negative bacteria such as HACEK organisms.

B) INCORRECT:

A combination of rifampin and vancomycin (in addition to gentamicin) is used to treat infective endocarditis (IE) caused by methicillin-resistant staphylococci in patients with prosthetic heart valves. This patient does not have a history of valve replacement, and the combination of rifampin and vancomycin is not a recommended regimen for the treatment of IE caused by HACEK organisms.

C) INCORRECT:

Penicillin G can be used for targeted antibiotic therapy of infective endocarditis that is caused by gram-positive organisms such as viridans streptococci and enterococci. Penicillin G is ineffective against most gram-negative pathogens including HACEK organisms.

D) INCORRECT:

Gentamicin is effective against gram-negative bacteria including HACEK organisms. However, gentamicin is both nephrotoxic and ototoxic, and the risk of developing one or more of the side effects of gentamicin is considerably higher if used for longer than 2 weeks. Since antibiotic therapy would be indicated for a minimum duration of 4 weeks in the case of infective endocarditis caused by C. hominis, a different antibiotic is preferred.

E) CORRECT:

Third-generation cephalosporins, such as ceftriaxone, have a broad spectrum coverage against gram-negative bacteria and are the treatment of choice for infective endocarditis caused by HACEK organisms. Alternative treatment regimens include fourth-generation cephalosporins, fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin), or ampicillin if in vitro susceptibility has been proven.

Key learning point: Third-generation cephalosporins like ceftriaxone are the treatment of choice for infective endocarditis caused by HACEK organisms.
questions.hint: Insidious onset of fatigue, low-grade fever, and shortness of breath in combination with a systolic heart murmur and splinter hemorrhages indicate subacute infective endocarditis (IE). Following identification of the causative pathogen on blood cultures, targeted antibiotic therapy should be employed to increase the efficacy of therapy and reduce the risk of side effects. HACEK organisms, such as Cardiobacterium hominis are highly susceptible, to a certain group of antibiotics.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a 3-day history of fever and malaise. He has a history of injection drug use. Vital signs are BP, 110/70; P, 95; T, 38.5°C (101.3°F). Physical examination shows a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border that was not present on a previous examination 6 months ago. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis with a left shift. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain three sets of blood cultures

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An electrocardiogram is indicated in all patients with suspected infective endocarditis to assess for new conduction abnormalities that may indicate perivalvular or myocardial abscess formation, such as atrioventricular block or bundle branch blocks. While an electrocardiogram is an important diagnostic test that should be performed, obtaining blood cultures takes priority as the most critical initial step for pathogen identification and guiding targeted therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

A urine drug screen is not part of the immediate management of suspected infective endocarditis. This patient's history of injection drug use has already been established, and confirming recent use does not change the clinical approach.

C) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotics should not be started until blood cultures are obtained, as antibiotic administration can result in negative cultures even in the presence of active infection.

D) INCORRECT:

While chest x-ray may be helpful to evaluate for pulmonary complications, it is not the most critical initial step if infective endocarditis is suspected.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has clinical features suggestive of infective endocarditis, including fever, a new cardiac murmur, and a history of injection drug use. The most important initial step is obtaining three sets of blood cultures from different venipuncture sites before initiating antibiotic therapy. Blood cultures are critical for pathogen identification and guide targeted antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with a history of mitral valve prolapse presents with 5 days of progressive dyspnea, intermittent fever, and malaise. She underwent dental extraction 3 weeks ago. Vital signs are T, 38.2°C (100.8°F); P, 92; BP, 135/85; R 14; oxygen saturation, 94% on room air. Physical examination shows a harsh holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex and bilateral lower extremity edema. Lung auscultation is notable for minimal bibasilar crackles. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis and elevated BNP. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Order chest CT angiography to evaluate for pulmonary embolism
Start empiric antibiotics immediately given acute heart failure
Obtain three sets of blood cultures from different sites and order transthoracic echocardiography
Order transesophageal echocardiography given the high-risk features
Initiate IV diuretics for heart failure management

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While dyspnea may suggest pulmonary embolism, this patient's fever, heart murmur, recent dental procedure, and signs of heart failure are much more consistent with infective endocarditis. The initial diagnostic approach should focus on blood cultures and echocardiography rather than CT angiography.

B) INCORRECT:

Starting empiric antibiotics before obtaining adequate blood cultures significantly compromises the diagnostic yield and can lead to false-negative results. Blood cultures should be drawn before antibiotic initiation whenever possible. Additionally, the initial diagnostic workup including echocardiography is essential for establishing the diagnosis and assessing complications.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's clinical presentation, including fever, heart murmur, a recent dental procedure, and manifestations of heart failure, strongly suggests infective endocarditis. The initial diagnostic approach requires three sets of blood cultures from different venipuncture sites obtained before antibiotic therapy and transthoracic echocardiography as the initial imaging study. This combination provides the essential microbiological and imaging components needed to meet the 2023 Duke-ISCVID criteria. Transesophageal echocardiography may be considered subsequently if transthoracic echocardiography is inconclusive or the patient has high-risk features.

D) INCORRECT:

While the patient has high-risk features such as heart failure, transthoracic echocardiography is the initial test of choice for all patients with suspected infective endocarditis. Transesophageal echocardiography is more invasive and should be considered after transthoracic echocardiography if findings are inconclusive or in certain cases with specific indications. Blood cultures must also be obtained as part of the initial diagnostic workup.

E) INCORRECT:

While this patient has clinical signs of heart failure (dyspnea, edema, elevated BNP), she does not have clinical signs of significant acute pulmonary edema requiring immediate diuretic therapy; the initial diagnostic workup for suspected infective endocarditis takes priority over heart failure treatment.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 5-day history of fever, chills, and progressive dyspnea. He was recently treated for urethritis. He appears acutely ill. Vital signs are T, 39.1°C (102.3°F); BP, 105/65, P, 115, and oxygen saturation 94% on room air. Needle marks are visible on both arms. Cardiac examination reveals a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur that is loudest at the left lower sternal border and increases with inspiration. Blood cultures are drawn and empiric antibiotics are initiated. Which predisposing factor most significantly increases the risk for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urinary tract infections and other distant bacterial infections can serve as sources of bacteremia that seed cardiac valves, but this represents a much lower risk compared to the direct introduction of bacteria through nonsterile intravenous drug use.

B) INCORRECT:

Dental procedures can cause transient bacteremia leading to infective endocarditis, particularly in patients with underlying valvular disease, but the risk is significantly lower than nonsterile intravenous drug use and typically affects abnormal native valves.

C) INCORRECT:

Poor dental hygiene is a risk factor for infective endocarditis. However, transient bacteremia from oral flora typically causes subacute endocarditis affecting previously damaged left-sided valves.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Nonsterile intravenous drug use is the highest risk factor for infective endocarditis in this patient. Intravenous drug use can lead to direct introduction of bacteria into the bloodstream through contaminated needles and injection practices. This patient's holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border that increases with inspiration is characteristic of tricuspid regurgitation, which commonly occurs in individuals with intravenous drug use due to right-sided endocarditis.

E) INCORRECT:

While male sex is a demographic risk factor for infective endocarditis, young age is not a significant risk factor. The major demographic risk factor is age greater than 60 years.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department 2 hours after sudden onset of left-sided weakness. He has had fever and malaise for the past 4 days. Vital signs are BP, 165/95; P, 110; R, 22; T, 38.8°C (101.8°F). Physical examination reveals left hemiparesis, left-sided neglect, small linear red streaks under several fingernails, and small, nontender, erythematous macules on the palms. Noncontrast head CT shows subtle loss of gray-white matter differentiation in the right middle cerebral artery territory with no hemorrhage. ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Laboratory studies show WBC 16,000/mm3 with 85% neutrophils and left shift, hemoglobin 11.2 g/dL, hematocrit 33%, platelets 450,000/mm3, troponin I 0.12 ng/mL (normal <0.04 ng/mL), and ESR 85 mm/hr. Urinalysis and chest x-ray are normal. Blood cultures are drawn, and IV antibiotics and fluids are initiated. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and clopidogrel

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute infective endocarditis is an absolute contraindication to thrombolytic therapy. This patient's presentation of fever for several days, peripheral embolic phenomena (splinter hemorrhages and Janeway lesions), elevated inflammatory markers, and acute stroke strongly suggests septic embolic stroke secondary to infective endocarditis. Therefore, tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) is inappropriate and potentially dangerous.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's presentation is most consistent with infective endocarditis. The ECG does not show signs of ischemia and the mild troponin elevation likely represents myocardial strain due to a systemic inflammatory response rather than an acute myocardial infarction. Troponin levels should be trended, but cardiac catheterization is not indicated at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's presentation suggests septic embolic stroke from infective endocarditis (IE). While antiplatelet therapy may eventually be considered in ischemic stroke, initiation of antithrombotic therapy is not routinely recommended in patients with IE. Additionally, DAPT is typically avoided in major strokes due to an increased risk of intracranial bleeding.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's combination of fever, peripheral embolic phenomena (splinter hemorrhages and Janeway lesions), elevated inflammatory markers, and acute stroke strongly suggests septic embolic stroke from infective endocarditis (IE). Up to one-third of patients with left-sided IE present with stroke symptoms. Echocardiography is essential to evaluate for valvular vegetations and confirm the suspected diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's presentation suggests septic embolic stroke from infective endocarditis (IE). Therapeutic anticoagulation is typically avoided in acute infective endocarditis due to an increased risk of hemorrhagic transformation of embolic infarcts and potential bleeding complications.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with a 5-day history of fever, malaise, and progressive shortness of breath. He has a history of rheumatic heart disease and reports a recent dental cleaning 3 weeks ago. Vital signs are T, 38.7°C (101.7°F); P, 108; BP, 110/65. Cardiac examination shows a harsh holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex with radiation to the left axilla. Laboratory results show leukocytosis with left shift. Blood cultures are obtained. What is the most appropriate initial empiric antibiotic regimen?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with suspected left-sided endocarditis involving the mitral valve based on his holosystolic murmur at the apex. The combination of rheumatic heart disease and a recent dental procedure places him at high risk for infective endocarditis. Vancomycin and ceftriaxone provide broad-spectrum coverage for both gram-positive (including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus and viridans streptococci) and gram-negative pathogens until culture results are available.

B) INCORRECT:

The combination of vancomycin, gentamicin, and rifampin is appropriate in selected cases (e.g., prosthetic valve infective endocarditis) and is usually started in consultation with infectious diseases. This patient has native valve disease.

C) INCORRECT:

While nafcillin provides excellent coverage for methicillin-susceptible staphylococci, it lacks coverage for MRSA and many streptococcal species. This regimen is insufficient as empiric therapy before determining organism susceptibilities.

D) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone alone provides coverage for HACEK organisms and some streptococci but lacks adequate coverage for staphylococci, which are common pathogens in infective endocarditis. Monotherapy is insufficient for empiric treatment of suspected endocarditis.

E) INCORRECT:

The combination of ampicillin and gentamicin is appropriate for enterococcal endocarditis but lacks adequate coverage for staphylococcal species, particularly methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. Given the patient's risk factors and presentation, broader empiric coverage is required before culture results are available.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of bicuspid aortic valve replacement 6 months prior presents with 3 days of chills, fatigue, exertional dyspnea, and orthopnea. Vital signs are BP, 128/76; P, 95; R, 24; T, 38.9°C (102°F). Oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. Physical examination shows increased work of breathing, a new systolic murmur, bilateral crackles, and scattered petechiae on the palms. Chest radiograph shows mild pulmonary vascular congestion. Transthoracic echocardiography shows a 12-mm vegetation on the prosthetic aortic valve with moderate regurgitation. Blood cultures are drawn, intravenous furosemide 40 mg is administered, and the patient is started on vancomycin, ceftriaxone, gentamicin, and rifampin. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Admit to the medical inpatient floor

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although transesophageal echocardiography provides better visualization of intracardiac complications and may be indicated for preoperative planning, transthoracic echocardiography findings and this patient's clinical presentation already establish prosthetic valve endocarditis with valve dysfunction. Urgent surgical consultation takes priority over additional imaging.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has prosthetic valve infective endocarditis complicated by valve dysfunction causing heart failure. Both prosthetic valve endocarditis and valve dysfunction causing heart failure are indications for urgent cardiothoracic surgery consultation. Early involvement of the multidisciplinary endocarditis team significantly improves outcomes.

C) INCORRECT:

Although intensive care unit admission may be appropriate for monitoring, this does not address the underlying need for urgent surgical evaluation. This patient requires cardiothoracic surgery consultation as the priority intervention for prosthetic valve endocarditis with valve dysfunction.

D) INCORRECT:

Inpatient dental evaluation is recommended for patients with infective endocarditis to treat dental sources of bacteremia and prevent recurrence. However, this is not the immediate priority when urgent surgical consultation is indicated for prosthetic valve endocarditis with heart failure.

E) INCORRECT:
